headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good evening, and thank you for joining E*TRADE's Fouth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. joining the call today are Chief Executive Officer, Mr. Paul Idzik; and Chief Financial Officer, Mr. Michael Pizzi. Today's call may include forward-looking sta
componenttext:
Good evening, and thank you for joining E*TRADE's Fouth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. joining the call today are Chief Executive Officer, Mr. Paul Idzik; and Chief Financial Officer, Mr. Michael Pizzi. Today's call may include forward-looking statements, which reflect management's current estimates or beliefs, and are subject to risks and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ materially. 
During the call, the company may also discuss non-GAAP financial measures. For a reconciliation of such non-GAAP measures to the comparable GAAP figures, and for a discussion of additional risks and uncertainties that may affect the future results of E*TRADE Financial, please refer to our earnings release furnished with Form 8-K and our 10-Ks, 10-Qs and other documents the company has filed with the SEC. 
All these documents are available at about.etrade.com. This call will present information as of January 21, 2016. The company disclaims any duty to update forward-looking statements made during the call. This call is being recorded and a replay will be available via phone and webcast later this evening at about.etrade.com. No other recordings or copies of this call are authorized or may be relied upon. 
With that, I will now turn the call over to Mr. Idzik.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Edison. Good evening, and thank you for joining us. As always, it is a pleasure to share my thoughts with you. Later Mr. Pizzi will dissect the quarter. But first, I'd like to spend some time reflecting on what has been, by all accounts, a bann
componenttext:
Thank you, Edison. Good evening, and thank you for joining us. As always, it is a pleasure to share my thoughts with you. Later Mr. Pizzi will dissect the quarter. But first, I'd like to spend some time reflecting on what has been, by all accounts, a banner year at E*TRADE. 
An adjusted net income of $340 million or $1.17 per share represent the company's strongest financial performance in nearly a decade, it is a product of exceptional efforts by our colleagues across the organization. We've come so far as a company to bolster our financial competitive positions and in the hall of accomplishments, 2015 display case houses some of our most celebrated and hard earned trophies. 
During the year, our risk profile exhibited a step function improvement as the continued reduction of legacy assets was marked by 2 consecutive quarters of lowering reserves while our demonstration of enhanced enterprise risk controls, among other things, helped solidify our regulatory standing. We embarked upon 4 major capital deployment actions emblematic of our improved position and greater flexibility. And most importantly, we focused on the customer experience, bringing several digital enhancements and offerings to market while further sharpening our focus through the discontinuation of noncore businesses. 
Let's start with our financial position. Faced with tremendous opportunity, my colleagues rose to the challenge, exceeding even our own demanding expectations. To provide a highlight reel of our triumphs, we kicked off 2015 announcing regulatory approval to reduce our bank's Tier 1 leverage ratio by 50 basis points to a level of 9%; reduced and refinanced our corporate debt through our target level of $1 billion at a blended average coupon of 5%, the lowest in company history; simplified our operating structure by extracting our broker-dealer subsidiaries from the bank, which now serves as a more efficient source of capital for the parent, distributed more than $800 million of excess capital to the parent; terminated costly legacy funding sources from our balance sheet markedly improving its profile returns while creating capacity for fuel growth with core customer deposits. 
And began the process of growing the balance sheet to a target of circa $49.5 billion. Put in place, we began executing on an $800 million share repurchase program. And finally, announced yet another approval to reduce our targeted bank leverage ratio in early 2016, this time by 100 basis points to 8%, a full year ahead of expectations. Our accomplishments numbered large and were significant in scope and we ended the year in a dominant stronger position than we began in and frankly, better than the company has been in more than a decade. 
Notably, our progress resulting position were recognized by our regulators and rating agencies across a few dimensions. First, we use at both the bank and parent were lifted early in the year. Next, reflective of our much improved risk profile and regulatory standing, our FDIC insurance rates were cut by more than half. And finally, we received investment-grade credit ratings for the first time in company history, following 7 notches of cumulative upgrades from our 2 covering agencies during the year, with a BBB designation from S&P in August and Moody's following suit in the December. 
While it is more than a pleasure to look back on these achievements, make no mistake that we are acutely focused on what is next, marked by our unwavering commitment to be faithful stewards of shareholder capital. To that end, we are currently in the midst of executing 2 important initiatives. First, we are steadily marching towards our target balance sheet size of $49.5 billion, which we expect to achieve in the second quarter. Second, we are actively executing on our $800 million share repurchase program announced in November. Through year-end, we repurchased 50 million and at a generated date, we have put another $26 million to work. 
Meanwhile, we continue to evaluate other possibilities for capital deployment. Beyond making prudent investments in the business, chief among these possibilities are potential acquisitions. I mentioned that we think of these in 3 broad categories, of which 2 continue to rise at the top of the list. Those are scale acquisitions in the brokerage business and opportunities to better capitalize on our customer deposits through banking. On the brokerage side, we have superior platforms and systems in place and utilizing the scale inherent there in is attractive. 
On banking, we see value in optimizing our low-cost stable deposits through a more favorable approach. While an abundance of small and medium-size opportunities exist in these areas, we are staying highly objective with an eye on delivering compelling returns on capital, ensuring our customers will be well served and the remaining close to our digital repos. As we examine specific opportunities, management and our board passed each through a robust filter, ensuring our heightened standards for risk, our demonstrated commitment to creating value for shareholders and our regulatory standing are at the forefront of any decisions.  
Irrespective of acquisitions, as we think about both growth and capital deployment, we have started to work on sizing the implications of exceeding $50 billion in assets. While I remain hopeful that logic rears its noble head and that certain relations might change, we take a more pragmatic approach to managing our business. Accordingly, I charged Mr. Pizzi and team of understanding all elements crossing this threshold, from systems to reporting to personnel, and most relevant for your purposes, costs. While there's still a lot of analysis to do and the numbers will be refined, initial estimates suggest about $50 million over 2 years related to getting in shape with an additional recurring component of approximately $15 million, annually. 
Keep in mind that not all of these costs, specifically those related to the initial build out, would have immediate P&L impact. Mr. Pizzi will cover more on that later. These costs are certainly not insignificant. And as we noted on numerous occasions, tip toeing over the $50 billion line won't benefit our owners, particularly in the current rate environment. However, with cost and benefits were clearly defined, we will be able to make an informed decision considering rates, growth and return on capital. So we're spending a healthy amount of time working through this exercise for the avoidance of any doubt, our intent for the foreseeable future is to manage our balance sheet to our stated target and not across the nifty land to 50. 
While on the top of expenses, the team has completed the budgeting work for 2016, and I would like to give some color on how we are thinking about spend going forward. We have made a lot of important investments in the business over the past few years, in particular, fortifying the company's risk and control framework in line with our enhanced expectations; bolstering our foundations through improved systems and infrastructure; and finally, upgrading talent. With much of the foundational work complete, we have really just begun to shift our dollars to chip away at delivering enhancements through the year towards improving our competitive position. 
Today, with this more rational expense structure, we are transitioning the way we think and talk about overall spending to be more directly in line with the revenue environment, meaning operating margin. On this measure for 2016, we expect it to be 39%. There are substantial upside in a more normalized rate environment where our target should move to the mid 40s range. While Mr. Pizzi will share additional thoughts and expenses in the coming quarter, I wanted to accentuate our revamped approach on the matter. 
Turning to our business metrics. Customer activity rates slowed in this global and macroeconomic uncertainty during the year, with DARTs of 155,000 down 8% from 2014. Q4 continued to try the moderation as DARTs of 147,000 were down 6% from the third quarter. Options during the quarter, were stable at 24% of total DARTs, consistent with our full-year mix. In January to date, we see an uptick in training activity in this volatile markets and in line with seasonal patterns. Through yesterday, DARTs are tracking up 26% from December. 
Despite uncertainty in the markets our customers showed confidence when they acted as they were net buyers of $6.8 billion securities during the year and maintained relatively healthy margin balances throughout, ending the year at $7.4 billion. For the quarter, margin balances averaged $7.5 billion down from $8 billion last quarter. Recently, we've seen a decline to about $7 billion. Despite the macroeconomic morass, our core franchise also continued its steady growth, adding 13,000 net new brokerage accounts during the fourth quarter, bringing the full-year total to 96,000 after we adjust for unique items. 
Our adjusted attrition rate for the quarter of 8.2% improved from 9.3% in the prior quarter, that brings our full year adjusted attrition rate to 8.9% in line with 2014 in a range that we think is healthy, given our business model. We brought in $2.8 billion of net new brokerage assets during the quarter, which was up from $2.1 billion in the third quarter, that brings our full year total to $9.3 billion, representing a 3.8% growth rate. Importantly, approximately 1/3 of those net new assets were flows into retirement accounts. 
Retirement investing in savings continue to represent a key component of our future growth, both our challenge and our opportunity is to better engage our customers to broaden their awareness and showcase our capabilities as a provider of investment solutions for both the near and long-term focus. We ended the year with $48 billion of retirement assets with our 880,000 retirement house, both of which increased modestly during the year. We also have $3.2 billion of assets and managed accounts, which we think complements this component of our business quite nicely. 
Another tremendous area of opportunity for us is our Stock Plan Administration business. We continue to invest in this business during the year and completed the transition of clients onto our award-winning Equity Edge Online platform. During the year, we added 144,000 net new accounts in this business and ended the year with 1.4 million planned participants. 
Turning to the enhancements we've made to our digital storefront and core platforms, leading with E*TRADE.com, we launched a new welcome page for prospective customers to better deliver our value proposition the moment a window shopper steps into the store. While it is in the early days, we have see an improvement in the funding rate for the accounts directed to this page. It was up over 2.5 percentage points compared to our prior experience. Once in the door, all customers were met with several overhauled sections of our site, including a revamped account overview page, our new retirement center, which provide a simple interface and inviting content to help customers engage, take charge and keep their goals on track. Our new tax center, which brings more efficiency and ease to a process that is notoriously stressful and convoluted. 
And finally, this morning, we announced the introduction of tip ranks to our platform. In listening to customers, we heard a strong need for help navigating the scores of public content across social and financial channels. The tool, which presents analyst settlement on individual stocks in an ultra clear way, takes a unique algorithm-based approach in analyzing it, aggregating representation to more than 3,700 cell site analysts and 4,500 financial bloggers. 
Turning to our active trader platform, E*TRADE Pro, we made a number of upgrades to further equip retail investors with professional grade tools. The big ticket items include a new options analyzer, which simplifies very complex strategies. In addition to a new streamlined design, the revamped tool enables traders to build multiple option strategies, mounting various strike in 8 scenarios, customize graphing features and more seamlessly than any strategy for trading. 
And our new margin analyzer, which provides greater clarity by way of a new detailed overview of buying power, explaining real-time requirements for each position in the customers portfolio. Lastly, is mobile, which continues to become a more prevalent component of our offering as mobile DARTs were a record 14% of our total DARTs in 2015 and 15% in Q4. Customers seek an experience that rival the desktop in terms of power and depth. And this year, we delivered robust enhancements to further empower customer on the go. 
Some of them were noteworthy features we added this year include, conditional orders to help customers more nimbly seize opportunities based on different market conditions; multi-leg options to execute complex strategies; bespoke mutual fund trading experience that embraces the unique form factor, and several new technologies available on Apple products, including home screen support of iOS, Apple Pay, and of course, our Apple Watch app where we're the only broker among our peers to offer account level data. 
When it comes to the progress of our digital offerings, we received significant third-party recognition this year, including earning 4 out of 5 stars overall in 2015 Broker Review, 3 First Place awards along with 5 best-in-class ratings and stockbrokers.com 2015 review. And for the fourth year running, Equity Edge Online was rated #1 for client satisfaction and loyalty by Group 5.
So in summary, 2015 was a great year for E*TRADE. We're very proud of the accomplish we made, but recognize, there's more to do to drive growth in the metrics and I know we can do better. So as we turn the page to a new year, I'm enthusiastic about the many initiatives we have underway to enhance our offering and grow our franchise, all while keeping focused on continuing to deliver value for shareholders. I am eager to share our progress along the way and I'm confident 2016 will be another great year for E*TRADE. 
And with that, I will turn it over to our CFO, Mr. Pizzi.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mr. Idzik. I'll start with our results. For the quarter, we reported earnings of $89 million or $0.30 per share. That compares to $98 million or $0.33 per share in the prior quarter after excluding the impact of the wholesale funding transactio
componenttext:
Thank you, Mr. Idzik. I'll start with our results. For the quarter, we reported earnings of $89 million or $0.30 per share. That compares to $98 million or $0.33 per share in the prior quarter after excluding the impact of the wholesale funding transaction. It also compares to adjusted net income of $78 million or $0.26 per share in the year-ago quarter after excluding early extinguishment of corporate debt. The quarter also included an elevated tax rate of 43% largely related to the impact of our wholesale funding transaction on the full year's pretax income and the associated impact on nondeductible items. 
We expected to return to a more normalized 30% to 40% range in 2016. Revenues were $454 million, up from an adjusted $443 million in the prior quarter, attributable to higher net interest spread, but down from $461 million in the year-ago quarter as a result of lower customer activity. Net interest income of $285 million improved $22 million from the prior quarter, driven by a healthy 30 basis point improvement in spread primarily related to the elimination of expensive wholesale funding, partially offset by a $1 billion lower average balance sheet, again the result of the wholesale elimination. 
Spread for the quarter was 288 basis points, above the high 270s range we discussed in the last call as a result of better marginal yields, coupled with meaningfully slower prepayment fees within our securities portfolio. As for 2016 spread, holding the Fed funds rate constant and doing the same for our most erratic variables relative to where they end the year, margin, stock lending and prepayment fees, we expect our spread for the year to be in the 270 to 275 basis point range with Q1 in the high 270s [ph]. I would note that with margin relative to where it ended the year, there is some downside. 
Commissions, fees and service charges and other revenues were $160 million, down $10 million from the prior quarter and down $16 million versus the year-ago quarter, largely attributable to a decline in trading activity relative to both periods. Average commission for trade of $10.66 declined $0.21 from the prior quarter and $0.18 from the year-ago quarter. The sequential decrease was driven by a higher mix of Active Traders and fewer contracts per option trade. The year-over-year decline was also driven by a higher mix of Active Traders. 
Securities gains were $9 million compared with an adjusted $10 million in the prior quarter. For the full year, we expect gains to be in the $30 to $40 million though any given quarter could vary. Expenses for the quarter were $305 million, up $12 million from the prior quarter, influenced by a couple of unique items. First, we had $6 million of executive severance within the restructuring line. Second, we had an $8 million onetime third-party contract charge in the communications line. Excluding those 2 items, expenses were $291 million. 
Looking ahead, we are truly shifting our framework to be more aligned with the revenue environment and that is evident in the investments we are making going forward. These investments are ones that will have a more direct impact on the growth in our business. As for the most significant drivers of the current year's expense guidance, which is predicated on an operating margin of 39%, they are the following: first, the impact of adding talent. We grew headcount in 2015 and we'll have the full year run rate of those additions as well as continue hiring throughout 2016. 
In 2015, many of the hires we made related to foundational enhancements and improvement to project management. In 2016, many of the hires we make will be related to business growth. In conjunction with this, we expect consultant headcounts to decline, which is captured in professional services. Second, we plan to increase our marketing spend in the high single-digit percentage range during the year. We maintained flexibility here and will be mindful of what market conditions warrant. And last, the impact of our reduced FDIC insurance premiums. We had a drop in our assessment rate mid 2015 and will recognize the full benefit of that in 2016. We expect this expense to be approximately $6 million per quarter with a $49.5 billion balance sheet. 
So those are the piece that will impact the full year. More specifically for Q1, we expect operating expenses to be around $310 million, which includes a sequential uptick in marketing spend. That combined with a smaller balance sheet we'll have in Q1 relative to the rest of the year will cause our op margin for the quarter to be below our full-year guidance. And to be clear on our operating margin guidance. The metric is aligned with our -- with that, which we report in our key performance metrics and is the percentage we make on revenue after provision and operating expenses, meeting it excludes corporate expense and other below the line items. We view this metric as an important measure of how we are managing the business. 
Moving on to the loan portfolio. It ended the year at $5 billion, down 6% during the quarter, and down 22% for the full year. The allowance reduced yet again, as we continue to see positive performance relative to our expectations, ending the quarter $353 million, a $23 million decline from the prior quarter. This translated into the benefits to provisions for loan losses of $23 million as net charge-offs were 0. 
With respect to HELOCs, we began 2015 with $600 million of HELOCs scheduled to convert to amortizing payments or mature during the year. We manage through the first significant volume of conversions and maturities, and we now have a sizable sample of converted loan performance to measure against our original expectations. We entered 2016 armed with even more data to forecast the performance of the future conversions and maturities. 
This year, we have about $800 million of our total $2.1 billion of home equity loans, of which $1.7 billion our HELOC scheduled to do so. So here's what I would emphasize on the topic. In the month of HELOC converts from an interest-only to an amortizing payment, we observed a significant increase in the rate of new 30-day delinquencies would ultimately results in the default rate approximately twice that of the non-converting population. 
Translating that into actual loss terms, the 24-month benchmark on non-converting loans has been about 6% while those that have converted are closer to 12%. Furthermore, the charge off occurs approximately 6 to 9 months after the conversion event when the loan reaches 180 days past due consistent with our standard accounting process for mortgage loan charge-offs. 
And finally our loss estimates incorporate our assumption on loans, converting in 2016 are generally at poor credit quality than the average converted loans to date, as national housing values peaked in 2006 when most of them originated, translating to higher CLT and less equities in the properties -- less equity in the properties today. These conversions and their performance are the single largest factor impacting our loss modeling, and while we expect charge-offs to increase in 2016, we are comfortable with our current level of reserves and continue it to expect provision expense for the year to be near 0. 
Moving on to capital. We announced 4 major deployment capital employment actions in 2014 and we are in the midst of executing  on 2 of them, balance sheet growth and share repurchases. On balance sheet growth, we expect to reach our targeted balance sheet size in Q2. 
At that point, our pro forma basis, we would be left with about $7 [ph] billion of off balance sheet deposits. Before assuming any level of growth in the bus, $2 billion of these deposits could be brought on the balance sheet at our direction. So taking this into account, and again, before assuming any level of customer cash growth, we have the ability to cross $50 billion organically.
To expand on Paul's comments regarding the work underway to size the impact of expenses across $50 billion in assets. First, we would have the upfront nonrecurring expenses to implement the qualitative requirements associated with crossing the threshold. More specifically, those are tied to requirement scripted under Dodd Frank, namely CCAR, the liquidity coverage ratio and resolution plan. Within the rough initial estimate of $50 million, we are still -- we're doing much work to determine what the final number will be and what portion of that would actually flow through the P&L versus how much will be capitalized. This does not include any additional FDIC costs, which would be incurred at a rate relatively aligned with our cost today. 
With respect to the $15 million estimate of recurring annual expenses that would be predominantly associated with additional headcount in various legal compliance and financial roles. But while the work -- while we work through these calculations, it is important to note that we will only cross the $50 billion threshold, if doing so presents compelling returns. Lastly, with respect to corporate cash. We ended the quarter with $447 million, up $15 million from the prior quarter as a $50 million dividend for each of our securities were offset by these $15 million repurchased shares. 
As a reminder, we intend to resume quarterly dividends from the Bank to the parent in Q1, and in light of our reduced Tier 1 leverage threshold to 8% at the bank this quarter, we intend to request dividends in excess of its $97 million of Q4 net income. 
And with that, operator, we will open the call for questions.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Rich Repetto from Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Rich Repetto from Sandler O'Neill.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, my first question is a follow-up to the 50 [ph] sort of research, 50 that you've done on the cost. And when you talk about a compelling return, I just wanted to get a little bit more color, what you sort of categorized as a compelling return. Bec
componenttext: I guess, my first question is a follow-up to the 50 [ph] sort of research, 50 that you've done on the cost. And when you talk about a compelling return, I just wanted to get a little bit more color, what you sort of categorized as a compelling return. Because -- and then, it looks like you would still have $2 billion in suite or off-balance sheet deposits you could add. So that would give you some growth, but where could you see growth coming from -- on the deposit side to actually get that compelling return on the 50 cost?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, a couple of things I would point out there, Rich. One, the $2 billion doesn't assume any growth in cash. That's really where we -- what the calculations would be, granted as of 12/31. Continuing -- if you look at our customer cash balances over time
componenttext: Well, a couple of things I would point out there, Rich. One, the $2 billion doesn't assume any growth in cash. That's really where we -- what the calculations would be, granted as of 12/31. Continuing -- if you look at our customer cash balances over time and in trends, you'll see that over time, they have been growing. So we would expect that number to grow with our business as we grow accounting of our customers. The $2 billion that we have there, think about what we give as our reinvestment rate of essentially 175 basis points or so, you can use that to estimate the revenue that will be available on that $2 billion [ph]. When we think of returns, we're not really just talking about the dollar return or margin, but we have to put equity against that balance sheet. So what we're really talking about is a compelling ROE to grow the balance sheet to 50 [ph], taking into account those costs.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And I guess -- I'm sure that you're still working through a lot of the cost here. But anyway, I guess, my follow-up question would be, and this may not be as relevant today. But interest rate sensitivity, and it seems like the other
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And I guess -- I'm sure that you're still working through a lot of the cost here. But anyway, I guess, my follow-up question would be, and this may not be as relevant today. But interest rate sensitivity, and it seems like the other e-brokers get specific in regards to how they would be impacted by rate hikes whether they happen or whether it is likely and that was before. But with the wholesale funding cleanup, are you able to give us a better idea of the interest rates subsidy for E*TRADE?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the past, with the various movements on the balance sheet, one, you could see the wholesale funding. But even the changes in the composition and cost of corporate debt, the pay downs and the loan portfolios, the deleveraging project to bring our balanc
componenttext: In the past, with the various movements on the balance sheet, one, you could see the wholesale funding. But even the changes in the composition and cost of corporate debt, the pay downs and the loan portfolios, the deleveraging project to bring our balance sheet down to get to our target capital ratio and then the sort of releveraging or bringing the balance sheet backup in size that we're doing now, we have shied away from giving that guidance. We are at a point now where we are completing some work, and I would say stay tuned because we're going to be coming -- we'll be coming with a more wholesome disclosures around our interest rate sensitivity.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you're thinking about it in the correct way, as rates move higher, the spread earned on that balance sheet will be larger. So we will need less balance to earn that compelling return, at a lower rate environment, we're going to need more balance.
componenttext: I think you're thinking about it in the correct way, as rates move higher, the spread earned on that balance sheet will be larger. So we will need less balance to earn that compelling return, at a lower rate environment, we're going to need more balance. Look at sort of the relative earnings on that relative to a reasonable equity cost and then therefore, return on equity that you want to achieve as a target and I think you can back into a number.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And maybe just switching over back to the -- and in discussion, I just wanted to get a sense as to -- given the guidance where we -- you indicated a rebasing, presumably in the asset yield side, if you can give some additional detail
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And maybe just switching over back to the -- and in discussion, I just wanted to get a sense as to -- given the guidance where we -- you indicated a rebasing, presumably in the asset yield side, if you can give some additional detail in terms of what assumptions are being made in certain items, particularly those that are more volatile like stock lending, but also in terms of security yields and the pro forma return.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the guidance we gave holds the -- some of those volatile components constant. So we're holding the margin balance constant at a rate that's level there. We're holding stock loan contribution consistent throughout that calculation. And then essentiall
componenttext: Yes, the guidance we gave holds the -- some of those volatile components constant. So we're holding the margin balance constant at a rate that's level there. We're holding stock loan contribution consistent throughout that calculation. And then essentially running a constant balance sheet of 49.5 to give you that spread guidance in the 270 to 275 basis points range. It also assumes no additional movements in federal funds.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just one final one for me. With the FDIC expense guidance, I'd say that you provided, does that contemplate the step up in fees that's expected later in the year?
componenttext: And just one final one for me. With the FDIC expense guidance, I'd say that you provided, does that contemplate the step up in fees that's expected later in the year?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The run rate expense guidance does not include any step up in fees. The step up in fees is out there as an issue. We expect it to get some closure some time in 2016. We've incorporated it into our planning and therefore, it is incorporated into the operat
componenttext: The run rate expense guidance does not include any step up in fees. The step up in fees is out there as an issue. We expect it to get some closure some time in 2016. We've incorporated it into our planning and therefore, it is incorporated into the operating margin guidance that we've given you, but the run rate -- we don't know the form that charge is going to take. It can be a onetime charge. It can be an ongoing assessment. It can actually be an element of both. Because of that, we have not factored it into the dollar guidance, but we have taken it into consideration in the calculation of the operating margin.

componenttext: Yes, I think as you can probably understand, we're operating under a plan and that's regarded throughout the amount that we've done thus far this year as we enter the quiet period late in December. With the movement in prices and volatility in the market, it's an item of active discussions between Paul and I, as to what the appropriate set of actions would be when we exit this period in a couple of days.

componenttext: And if I can just sneak in -- I'm sorry. headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The 1 75 is the marginal rate of reinvestment. So in terms of where we are effectively by duration margin securities in today's market, please keep in mind, yields have been exceptionally volatile as that spreads. So that number is bouncing around, we cou
componenttext: The 1 75 is the marginal rate of reinvestment. So in terms of where we are effectively by duration margin securities in today's market, please keep in mind, yields have been exceptionally volatile as that spreads. So that number is bouncing around, we could think of it as a range of 1.75% to 2% right now. We haven't historically disclosed our cost of equity, but it's actually a fairly straightforward calculation from a cap end model, so in terms of where we're coming out. But I think to confirm that, you're going to get around the 10% type range across.

componenttext: Yes, so move deposits back on the balance sheet and you are buying in the 1.75% to 2% range, you are giving up the fees that you are earning on the off balance sheet portion.

componenttext: Hey, Mike. Just on the expense outlook. So I know you just mentioned in the first quarter of the 3 10, it seems like that's a pretty decent bump up even with advertising from like the adjusted number that I think is around 2 90 in this quarter. So just wanted to see what's driving that. I know you mentioned advertising [indiscernible] accomplices, is there anything else that gets a lift in the first quarter?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, if you get back and look, you'll see that comp and ben is always the highest in the first quarter, that is really related to all of the tax items and resets that go on. So that'll be occurring as well as the ramp up in marketing. And then some of the
componenttext: Yes, if you get back and look, you'll see that comp and ben is always the highest in the first quarter, that is really related to all of the tax items and resets that go on. So that'll be occurring as well as the ramp up in marketing. And then some of the full-year headcount really, really continuing. But that's really more of -- for the full-year not just for the first quarter.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just in terms of going over the $50 billion. You guys gave a, I'm just curious when you think about getting positioned for that transition, if you determine that it makes sense. Like what's like the time ear line in terms of getting prepare
componenttext: Okay. And then just in terms of going over the $50 billion. You guys gave a, I'm just curious when you think about getting positioned for that transition, if you determine that it makes sense. Like what's like the time ear line in terms of getting prepared, is there any additional hiring? Andy additional system costs, meaning is it something that you guys have been planning as you have been kind of revamping the infrastructure that it wouldn't take that long? Or are you still thinking it can only take a few quarters to be building that out?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, I think that one, there is really no decision to cross at this point. We are working on a plan, but a plan is not a decision point. But I think at some point yes, with the growth in cash, it will become more and more likely decision. But at what poi
componenttext: Look, I think that one, there is really no decision to cross at this point. We are working on a plan, but a plan is not a decision point. But I think at some point yes, with the growth in cash, it will become more and more likely decision. But at what point that is, is it's a little bit off to the future. How the rules work? In some of the CCAR rules, you have 5 quarters to come into compliance with. So that gives you an operating window of time, but obviously, you want to have a very detailed and well thought out plan put in place before you start down that road, because you have a fixed window to get it in place. Other rules actually kick in, this is a heightened expectation rules. They kick in day 1 when you cross 50. So that work has to be done almost immediately, but some of that is a bit more structural. It's a bit more easier to put in place. As we step back from it, it's not going to take a full 2 years in terms of the expense period to go over 50. But there is going to be a period of ramp up time as you're building out the plan and as you're beginning on the execution of the first phase of the plan, particularly personnel to get some of this work done.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Chris Harris with Wells Fargo.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Another clearly, a really strong quarter in credit. And I appreciate your comments about expectations on default rates and the HELOC booke. But I'm just trying to square that with what you guys are actually reporting. So this is the third consecutive quar
componenttext: Another clearly, a really strong quarter in credit. And I appreciate your comments about expectations on default rates and the HELOC booke. But I'm just trying to square that with what you guys are actually reporting. So this is the third consecutive quarter of no charge-offs in the HELOC portfolio. So it seems like you guys are running way, way better than that. So help us maybe kind of bridge that loss experience as you're kind of reporting that versus where you think they potentially might be going?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I could probably give you a little bit of color on that. I think the gross charge-offs for the period were $21 million. That will be coming out in our 10-K when we file it, and we are seeing an elevated level of recoveries that are driving the net charge-
componenttext: I could probably give you a little bit of color on that. I think the gross charge-offs for the period were $21 million. That will be coming out in our 10-K when we file it, and we are seeing an elevated level of recoveries that are driving the net charge-off number to 0. But we expect that recovery stream to continue somewhat, but it has been exceptionally strong and we are coming up on increased conversion balances. So that really squares to how we get to the loss modeling and it supports the 3 53 allowance.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, that makes sense then. And then the commentary around acquisitions, would you guys consider acquiring a bank that had credit risk? Is that part of the potential candidates that you're considering?
componenttext: All right, that makes sense then. And then the commentary around acquisitions, would you guys consider acquiring a bank that had credit risk? Is that part of the potential candidates that you're considering?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chris, we're considering a number of strings across 3 dimensions, right, which we've talked about it on a couple of calls now. And let's remember the reason we brought this up is because we were incurred of in a period of time and couldn't entertain these
componenttext: Chris, we're considering a number of strings across 3 dimensions, right, which we've talked about it on a couple of calls now. And let's remember the reason we brought this up is because we were incurred of in a period of time and couldn't entertain these at all. So as the music's changed here, we wanted to make sure that we were very clear with the Street, with the sell-side, with our investors that we're now in a different spot and we can't entertain these things. As we said, 2 of those, 3 categories have emerged as having more potential attractive opportunities and I say, potential. One is certainly to find ways to add scale in the brokerage business because the operating leverage is so attractive. The second is in banking, finding a way to monetize the value of our customer deposits to a greater degree than we do today. And that would imply acquiring an institution that has strong capabilities and traditional intermediary activities.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

But during the quarter, I think you guys announced an expansion of your relationship with Jefferies, giving clients access to munies and you had a relationship in place for IPOs with the year now. So are there any other in demand products that could maybe be satisfied through more of our kind of partnership than anything else?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: That's a good question, Ken. We look at partnerships all the time. We recently got involved in a partnership in our back-office that we think not only provides customers with better service level, but provides us better economics. So we look at those all the time particularly as people produce new products. And if you think about the introduction tip ranks today, that's very much a partnership and that's providing some additional valued educational, and investing knowledge to our customers through partnerships. So we think about those all the time.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then just modeling question here for the commission. I know you guys, it drops quite a bit and one of the peers kind of stabilized, one a little higher. I know you mentioned some of the higher percentage of Active Traders in this quarter. Is there anything different that you're seeing from a customer base? Are you guys targeting a higher group of Active Traders or making it easier for them to trade at a discounted rate that might be kind of driving that lower over time or should we expect that to stabilize some?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, we're clearly continuing to invest in, for example, E*TRADE Pro, which unquestionably signals the fact that we are absolutely committed to serving the needs of those valued customers. And much of what you're introducing on the mobile devices, is also
componenttext: Ken, we're clearly continuing to invest in, for example, E*TRADE Pro, which unquestionably signals the fact that we are absolutely committed to serving the needs of those valued customers. And much of what you're introducing on the mobile devices, is also aimed at serving that valuable client base because they like to stay in touch and like to be able to take action when they want to take action. So our dedication to that area is very important. Our modeling on that metric that you just described is influenced by a number of factors and including the impact of our Corporate Services business, and a change in buying behavior is somewhat in the fourth quarter as people repositioned then a few more mutual fund type purchases as opposed to just straight DARTs -- straight equity trades. So there's a number of moving factors there.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd just like to make one correction to an earlier comment, to Connor's question. I gave the gross revenue number on the off balance sheet, the off balance sheets we've deposits. There are fees paid in that arrangement. So when I gave the number of 23 bas
componenttext: I'd just like to make one correction to an earlier comment, to Connor's question. I gave the gross revenue number on the off balance sheet, the off balance sheets we've deposits. There are fees paid in that arrangement. So when I gave the number of 23 basis points, we're actually in the 10 to 15 basis point range because we have to pay the administrator fees, so it's not as high as that. We also expect that to go up with the full quarter now of the post -- post the Federal Reserve increase into the 25 to 30 basis point range.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Devin Ryan with JMP.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Devin Ryan with JMP.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question here on excess liquidity. If this market volatility persists, does that change your view at all around the 2x debt service cushion? I know you're well above that now, but I'm just trying to think about what's truly excess. And then also, y
componenttext: Just a question here on excess liquidity. If this market volatility persists, does that change your view at all around the 2x debt service cushion? I know you're well above that now, but I'm just trying to think about what's truly excess. And then also, you're now being at the 8% Tier 1 leverage capital plan objective, that's great. Should we think about that as an ending point or is there still a goal to maybe move that lower over time?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take the second first. Devin, we just got the permission to take it down to 8. So you'll forgive us for, one, to catch our breath a bit. And I appreciate your impatience but we're going to catch our breath a bit. We do think as the loan portfolio con
componenttext: I'll take the second first. Devin, we just got the permission to take it down to 8. So you'll forgive us for, one, to catch our breath a bit. And I appreciate your impatience but we're going to catch our breath a bit. We do think as the loan portfolio continues to cure, that there's some more opportunity to take that down to a level that towards the 7 handle. But that's something that we want to carefully work through with our regulators and make sure that all the right people are comfortable before we even start entertaining that idea. So the dust has just begun to settle on the trophy of getting that done . So we're going to be patient and approach it in the same careful way we did in getting down to it -- down to 8. And then Mike is going to take the other question.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, on the 2x debt service, please keep in mind the 2x debt service is actually a -- coming in, in our revolver at this point in time. So we will not go below the $800 million number. We view corporate cash as sort of the ultimate resource of liquidity i
componenttext: Yes, on the 2x debt service, please keep in mind the 2x debt service is actually a -- coming in, in our revolver at this point in time. So we will not go below the $800 million number. We view corporate cash as sort of the ultimate resource of liquidity if we needed to use it between our legal entities and it's also a source of capital. So therefore, we are not going to operate at -- enter margins in that 2x level.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then with respect to the lending, the balances bounce around quite a bit, revenue tend to be less volatile there. So just because of the NIM guidance, with that line specifically, should we just think about a revenue level being relatively constant wi
componenttext: And then with respect to the lending, the balances bounce around quite a bit, revenue tend to be less volatile there. So just because of the NIM guidance, with that line specifically, should we just think about a revenue level being relatively constant with whatever it's been? Or just how should we think about that dynamic?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well within the NIM guidance, we are keeping it constant. Now constant doesn't mean the constant yield there. I mean it's a constant -- overall contribution. Keep in mind that the hard to borrow component that is essentially the rebates earned on the stoc
componenttext: Well within the NIM guidance, we are keeping it constant. Now constant doesn't mean the constant yield there. I mean it's a constant -- overall contribution. Keep in mind that the hard to borrow component that is essentially the rebates earned on the stock lending is put up to the borrowing line, and the borrowing balance is being driven by customer activity. So there's going to be a lot of volatility in the yield that's posted there. But from a dollar perspective, we expect to be relatively flat.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just finally, to be clear here, the operating margin expectation of 39%, that includes provision. I'm assuming I know that there's not much expected this year, but I just want to make sure that, that objective includes provision.
componenttext: And then just finally, to be clear here, the operating margin expectation of 39%, that includes provision. I'm assuming I know that there's not much expected this year, but I just want to make sure that, that objective includes provision.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That includes provision and our guidance on provision for the year is 0.
componenttext: That includes provision and our guidance on provision for the year is 0.

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Bedell with Deutsche Bank.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just to add on to that question on the 39% off margin with the provision. Should the provisions, you've got a great lead in either direction, do you view that as something that would change that operating margin? Or would you use that as sort of con
componenttext: Maybe just to add on to that question on the 39% off margin with the provision. Should the provisions, you've got a great lead in either direction, do you view that as something that would change that operating margin? Or would you use that as sort of contributing to that 39% target, either way?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as you'd expect, we have to react to that when it occurs. If provisions come in above what we anticipate, we'll have to look where we'll be able to lose other costs. Those numbers come in big and chunky though, so our ability to move the other numbe
componenttext: Well, as you'd expect, we have to react to that when it occurs. If provisions come in above what we anticipate, we'll have to look where we'll be able to lose other costs. Those numbers come in big and chunky though, so our ability to move the other numbers is not quite the flexibility you might have otherwise. And if it comes in better, we'll again take a look and see. We've oftentimes on these calls said we like to flex our marketing budget. And when times are good, invest in driving future customer growth and when times are bad, being as responsible as we can. So that's a bit -- something we have to handle day-to-day as we see what happens.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's great color. And then maybe just in brief bow, in the acquisition spectrum I guess, actually a question for both you and Mike. Mike, if you could talk a little bit about the financial metrics or hurdles for deals that you might be following in term
componenttext: That's great color. And then maybe just in brief bow, in the acquisition spectrum I guess, actually a question for both you and Mike. Mike, if you could talk a little bit about the financial metrics or hurdles for deals that you might be following in terms of either accretion, timeline or ROE. And then may be Paul, if you -- how do you feel about the RIA business is one of the big areas that you're not in, and I see that scaling your capabilities.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Why don't you take the metrics one first?
componenttext: Why don't you take the metrics one first?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, anything we're looking at is going to have a -- have to have an extremely compelling return in terms of the investments that we are making in terms of -- ROE or its return on invested capital. We would also expect accretion commensurate to the deal
componenttext: Sure, anything we're looking at is going to have a -- have to have an extremely compelling return in terms of the investments that we are making in terms of -- ROE or its return on invested capital. We would also expect accretion commensurate to the deal size and the risk in the deal. So we would expect higher metrics for deals that are going to be -- that have higher complexity with higher risks to them in terms of what we can achieve. I guess the only sort of thing that I would carve out of that is probably anything that's around the capability or product, that we haven't talked much about that. They would be allowed to be on the smaller site. But any larger amount or use of capital is going to have to have an extremely compelling return profile and accretion.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: On RIA, I -- we've been pretty consistent in our thinking on this, which is not really all that intrigued by that opportunity right now for 2 main reasons. One, we really want to see how the Department of Labor regulations that are mooded might turn out b
componenttext:
On RIA, I -- we've been pretty consistent in our thinking on this, which is not really all that intrigued by that opportunity right now for 2 main reasons. One, we really want to see how the Department of Labor regulations that are mooded might turn out because that could have quite a significant impact on that business. And secondly, if you're going to go in that business, I believe you need to enter that business from a -- with scale. And so that would also make us think twice about that. And so for right now, that's not quite in -- quite at the top of our mind.
I think we'll take, maybe 2 more? 2 more calls please, Edison.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Andrew Del Medico with Autonomous Research.

And I think considering the type of credit risk that we have been managing over the past several years and how it came on the books is not exactly what I would consider traditional banking business.

componenttext: Okay. I guess, what -- when you evaluate a potential bank acquisition, I guess what actual loan channels and assets would you really be looking at then?

componenttext: I think what I'd look at it -- when we think about things, we think about things that kind of compliment our existing business, our business model and how we go about things, the type of customers we have, will it have any resonance in with the E*TRADE Corporate Services business. And so those are the type of applications of our thinking and the direction we're taking.

So does the guidance for 2016, for the 39% pretax assume that you're going to be a ramp-up in headcount expense? And does that mean you would see some offsets elsewhere in the expense categories?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016

componenttext: The guidance includes our projected headcount, but it's not -- the headcount projection is not -- the continued growth rate is going to slow from what it has been. So you don't -- you're not necessarily going to see offsets. The hiring in the fourth quarter is very much around staffing up for the -- just for the tax season and the financial season that we enter at this time of year.

Do you have to change any customer agreements to bring those on balance sheet? And what would you anticipate the earning asset level to be if you were to bring on additional $2 billion in deposits?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're working through that and right now, in terms of the actual conversions that are underway. You'll notice that assets that are in off balance sheet came down as we brought some of our balance sheet. We have additional conversions that are going
componenttext: Well, we're working through that and right now, in terms of the actual conversions that are underway. You'll notice that assets that are in off balance sheet came down as we brought some of our balance sheet. We have additional conversions that are going to occur this quarter, but that's going to be a lot of process, bringing us to our target level of 49.5 by sometime in the second quarter. The additional $2 billion amount is really part of the same process if we wanted to bring it on, we could. The remaining amount for various reasons, it's either in money funds that the customer has chosen to be in the tax exempt products. It is money above the FDIC insurance threshold. So to be insured, it has to be held at a different bank. Therefore, it cannot be brought back onto our balance sheet, so of that 7, 5 of it cannot be brought back to -- can be brought back. That's what we gave in the prepared remarks. And then as we grow accounts and grow our business over time, we expect that 2 to grow.
