componenttext: Yes, Paul, Mike. The checking line definitely contributed here with the provision. I'm just trying to see, you don't expect it to contribute like it did, and is the performance that you're seeing there -- I know we still got half the amortization portfolio -- of the amortization portfolio to go, but are we still -- it just feels like we're conservative, given the last couple quarters and the amount of reversals we've seen in that line.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Mike's going to talk to it in more detail, but Rich, our models and what we have set aside goes through a tremendous amount of scrutiny, not only from our own people but from our accountancy firm and also from our regulators. So I just think we need
componenttext: Well, Mike's going to talk to it in more detail, but Rich, our models and what we have set aside goes through a tremendous amount of scrutiny, not only from our own people but from our accountancy firm and also from our regulators. So I just think we need to keep that in context as we think about it, but Mike, I know you have stuff to add here.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Rich, I would keep in mind that, as we move through time, we are moving into later vintage loans, with the loans this year being -- really converting in 2006 vintage. Next year, it would be 2007. So the remaining 50% is of vintages that are largely t
componenttext: Yes, Rich, I would keep in mind that, as we move through time, we are moving into later vintage loans, with the loans this year being -- really converting in 2006 vintage. Next year, it would be 2007. So the remaining 50% is of vintages that are largely thought to be of lower quality. So that may help put this in perspective a little bit. The other point I would call out is while we did have $3 million of recoveries through the charge-off line, they're not coming from the current loan population. And so that elevated recovery number that we see that's really been -- really very influential in the last few quarters is very difficult to forecast on a go-forward basis. And that's what contributes to coming out where we are on the current allowance.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay, helpful. And then just I'm going to ask about interest rate sensitivity. And we looked at the presentation, and it's hard to compare given the new -- the adjustments to the NII. But is there incremental -- like the spread in your presentatio
componenttext: Got it. Okay, helpful. And then just I'm going to ask about interest rate sensitivity. And we looked at the presentation, and it's hard to compare given the new -- the adjustments to the NII. But is there incremental -- like the spread in your presentation is wider. Has anything changed in regards to interest rate sensitivity?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very little change in regards to interest rate sensitivity. What I will say is given the movement in margin and the movements in cash, and you'll see a higher amount of segregated cash, those are the items that are directly influencing the small change in
componenttext: Very little change in regards to interest rate sensitivity. What I will say is given the movement in margin and the movements in cash, and you'll see a higher amount of segregated cash, those are the items that are directly influencing the small change in the delta in net interest income that you see.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. And then, I guess, my last question is on -- great quarter. It seemed like you beat on every revenue line, but margin loans did drop, it appears, a little bit more than peers. Anything going on? I know you mentioned, Paul, deleveraging of th
componenttext: Got it. Okay. And then, I guess, my last question is on -- great quarter. It seemed like you beat on every revenue line, but margin loans did drop, it appears, a little bit more than peers. Anything going on? I know you mentioned, Paul, deleveraging of the consumer, but can you give us some more color on the, I guess, it was, I think, 15% quarter-to-quarter?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich, you'll -- if you go back in history, you'll see that while margin balances were building up, ours were building a little faster. And as our customer base decided to derisk, they derisked a little faster and a little more steeply than the competition
componenttext: Rich, you'll -- if you go back in history, you'll see that while margin balances were building up, ours were building a little faster. And as our customer base decided to derisk, they derisked a little faster and a little more steeply than the competition. So I think it's just a question of the makeup of the relative customer books.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Conor Fitzgerald with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Conor Fitzgerald with Goldman Sachs.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Paul, I just want to go back to your comments on, I think, managing the business to the adjusted pretax margin, so excluding the reserves release. I think, on the last quarter call, you kind of left the door open for maybe reinvesting reserve release,
componenttext: So Paul, I just want to go back to your comments on, I think, managing the business to the adjusted pretax margin, so excluding the reserves release. I think, on the last quarter call, you kind of left the door open for maybe reinvesting reserve release, if they were stronger than you expected, back in the business. Should we kind of interpret your comment today as reserve release is totally divorced from your expenses?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think what we said is we don't see it as a license to just spend it without regard to our other targets and other obligations we have, both to our owners and other things we're trying to accomplish. So that's what we're trying to point to, as well a
componenttext: No. I think what we said is we don't see it as a license to just spend it without regard to our other targets and other obligations we have, both to our owners and other things we're trying to accomplish. So that's what we're trying to point to, as well as saying, if we have worse-than-expected charges, that we would try and still keep to our target. So that's -- I think what you're hearing us talk about, Conor, is just trying to continue to be as disciplined as we can in managing through the type of results that we think our owners deserve. If we thought we could put some additional cash to work wisely, we would be happy to tell you about that.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then, again on the buyback, I appreciate the comments around the timing and the 7% floor. But if you were to get kind of more aggressive, is it more in your mind you just want to be more deliberate from here on out? Or are you kind of trying t
componenttext: Got it. And then, again on the buyback, I appreciate the comments around the timing and the 7% floor. But if you were to get kind of more aggressive, is it more in your mind you just want to be more deliberate from here on out? Or are you kind of trying to maybe respond to share price movements? When you think about kind of the pace and the timing, is it more steady? Or are you going to try and be a little more dynamic?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you saw an acceleration in the quarter. That was definitely in response to the market. I think we will remain as dynamic as we can be within the confines of our capital and corporate cash to respond to the overall market environment. But as
componenttext: Well, I think you saw an acceleration in the quarter. That was definitely in response to the market. I think we will remain as dynamic as we can be within the confines of our capital and corporate cash to respond to the overall market environment. But as we said on the call, we see finishing this, really, within the year, really 1 quarter ahead of the authorization timing.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Harris with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Harris with Wells Fargo.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to come back to the NIM for a second. The 290 or so that you talked about, 294, I guess, it was, for the quarter. What was it that happened that really surprised to the upside? Was it the flow-through on rates? The Fed rate hike being a little
componenttext: Just wanted to come back to the NIM for a second. The 290 or so that you talked about, 294, I guess, it was, for the quarter. What was it that happened that really surprised to the upside? Was it the flow-through on rates? The Fed rate hike being a little bit stronger than maybe you guys had anticipated, is that what drove a lot of it? Just trying to square that relative to the original guidance.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the Fed rate hike did drive some of it, but that was contemplated within the guidance. The main driver of outperformance versus the guidance really had to do with lower-than-expected -- substantially lower-than-expected prepayment speeds on the secu
componenttext: Well, the Fed rate hike did drive some of it, but that was contemplated within the guidance. The main driver of outperformance versus the guidance really had to do with lower-than-expected -- substantially lower-than-expected prepayment speeds on the securities portfolio. And then you'll see that even though the margin balance declined, the rate is up more than what the Fed move would suggest, meaning the balances that left were at a much lower rate than the average for the portfolio.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you, okay. I was going to ask a question on the margin loan, so that was good. All right. Ameritrade, on their call, they talked a little bit about some expenses for DOL. Any thoughts there, guys, whether you've kind of taken a look at that? I mean, I
componenttext: Got you, okay. I was going to ask a question on the margin loan, so that was good. All right. Ameritrade, on their call, they talked a little bit about some expenses for DOL. Any thoughts there, guys, whether you've kind of taken a look at that? I mean, I know we've really just gotten the final ruling out, but anything you could help us there as far as perhaps magnitude or anything qualitatively as well?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I didn't listen to the TD Ameritrade call, but we anticipate being able to meet our DOL obligations within the target guidance we've given for operating margin. As we've gone through and seen what's occurring out of the regs, we feel our model stands up v
componenttext: I didn't listen to the TD Ameritrade call, but we anticipate being able to meet our DOL obligations within the target guidance we've given for operating margin. As we've gone through and seen what's occurring out of the regs, we feel our model stands up very well with us not having proprietary product, us having compensation practices that are close to what's desired, as it is. And so we're pretty confident we're going to be able to continue to try and drive towards our target operating margin.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Steven Chubak with Nomura.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Steven Chubak with Nomura.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I figure I'll kick things off with a question on capital ratios. You noted that you intend to request that incremental 50 basis point reduction in your targeted bank leverage to 7.5% next year. I just wanted to get a sense as to whether 7% is a reasona
componenttext: So I figure I'll kick things off with a question on capital ratios. You noted that you intend to request that incremental 50 basis point reduction in your targeted bank leverage to 7.5% next year. I just wanted to get a sense as to whether 7% is a reasonable endgame target that you guys are still contemplating, which, from your remarks, is consistent with what you're managing to at the parent today.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Steven, we do see others in the industry have a target -- have a 7% handle. And when Mike and I wistfully look across the horizon as the sun sets, our eyes do twinkle thinking about the ability to get down to 7%. I think it's probably a reasonable a
componenttext: Well, Steven, we do see others in the industry have a target -- have a 7% handle. And when Mike and I wistfully look across the horizon as the sun sets, our eyes do twinkle thinking about the ability to get down to 7%. I think it's probably a reasonable aspiration we have. And we'll just continue doing what we've been doing in terms of improving our risk profile, taking regulatory guidance seriously, working hard to keep strengthening our enterprise risk management. And with all those things and with the close supervision of our regulators, we're hopeful that we'll be able to get down more towards where we see other competitors in a reasonable period of time.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. Well, thinking about that pro forma balance sheet, Paul, which brings a twinkle in your eye, I know in the past you had spoken about some potential benefits linked to a portfolio sale, and recognizing there are some different puts and takes, b
componenttext: Understood. Well, thinking about that pro forma balance sheet, Paul, which brings a twinkle in your eye, I know in the past you had spoken about some potential benefits linked to a portfolio sale, and recognizing there are some different puts and takes, but given the favorable credit performance we've seen, and now that you're halfway through with the amortizing HELOCs, is that still an attractive avenue worth pursuing? And does the secondary market actually accommodate that at the moment?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, right now, we still think that holding those assets is in our shareholders' best interest. We, of course, continue to take soundings in the market, and if we felt a better solution would be to sell those to other people, we would certainly do so. An
componenttext: Well, right now, we still think that holding those assets is in our shareholders' best interest. We, of course, continue to take soundings in the market, and if we felt a better solution would be to sell those to other people, we would certainly do so. And you have my phone number, and if you want to buy them, Steven, you just give us a call, and we'll talk about it at some point.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Unfortunately, I don't think I have deep enough pockets, Paul, but thank you for the offer. And maybe just one more quick one for me. I was hoping you can just give an update on any plans you might have to extinguish the $400 million-or-so TruPS, just giv
componenttext: Unfortunately, I don't think I have deep enough pockets, Paul, but thank you for the offer. And maybe just one more quick one for me. I was hoping you can just give an update on any plans you might have to extinguish the $400 million-or-so TruPS, just given that the securities, as of the end of this year, are now fully disallowed from Tier 1 capital.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Steven. If we look at the securities, they remain reasonably attractive from a debt spread perspective in terms of issuance. So we view them as really just liabilities at this point. To the extent that because they're somewhat illiquid, we see second
componenttext: Yes, Steven. If we look at the securities, they remain reasonably attractive from a debt spread perspective in terms of issuance. So we view them as really just liabilities at this point. To the extent that because they're somewhat illiquid, we see secondary trading in them or someone's looking to move them, we will, from time to time, participate there as they can be purchased at a discount. But we have no intent to exercise the regulatory call.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Steven, that's, an order of magnitude, less than the loan. So we'll also take a call from you on the TruPS.
componenttext: And Steven, that's, an order of magnitude, less than the loan. So we'll also take a call from you on the TruPS.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Dan Fannon with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Dan Fannon with Jefferies.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, I appreciate the additional color around the M&A kind of strategy and the outlook. I guess, if you could give some additional commentary maybe around just the current environment, there was some activity in the market and the industry this quarter.
componenttext: Paul, I appreciate the additional color around the M&A kind of strategy and the outlook. I guess, if you could give some additional commentary maybe around just the current environment, there was some activity in the market and the industry this quarter. I guess, how would you characterize the opportunity set in terms of pricing or actual available properties today?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, you guys are as aware as -- probably more aware than almost anyone else regarding what type things might fit into each of those categories. But I'll take this opportunity to say that neither Michael nor I nor our board is going to have us overpay fo
componenttext: Well, you guys are as aware as -- probably more aware than almost anyone else regarding what type things might fit into each of those categories. But I'll take this opportunity to say that neither Michael nor I nor our board is going to have us overpay for any property. And I think that's about all we need to say.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess, just, Mike, a question on NIM. The guidance going into next quarter, the margin balances are down, but I think, in a previous answer to a question, you highlighted that the rates are up. So just curious as to kind of the outlook in the
componenttext: Okay. And I guess, just, Mike, a question on NIM. The guidance going into next quarter, the margin balances are down, but I think, in a previous answer to a question, you highlighted that the rates are up. So just curious as to kind of the outlook in the decline, I guess, roughly 15-or-so basis points quarter-over-quarter and the drivers of that?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, we're anticipating some normalization in the overall security speeds from the very low level that they were in the first quarter of the year. That's going to be the primary driver of the decline in the securities yields that we're expecting t
componenttext: Yes. I mean, we're anticipating some normalization in the overall security speeds from the very low level that they were in the first quarter of the year. That's going to be the primary driver of the decline in the securities yields that we're expecting to get to the guidance range for next quarter and for the full year.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Devin Ryan with JMP Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Devin Ryan with JMP Securities.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just a follow-up here on just DOL considerations. I definitely appreciate that you guys don't anticipate big implications around the ability to provide services for clients. But I'm just trying to think, in the near term, are there any consideration
componenttext: Maybe just a follow-up here on just DOL considerations. I definitely appreciate that you guys don't anticipate big implications around the ability to provide services for clients. But I'm just trying to think, in the near term, are there any considerations that you guys are thinking about? I'm not sure if we see a slowdown in rollover activity just for some period as the final rule is being digested or maybe -- or even on the positive side, some evidence that more money is moving towards self-directed, just as it's fallen through the cracks at the brokerage firms on the retail side. I mean, I'm just curious if there's any other considerations we're not talking about.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think there's a whole host of -- irrespective of what firm you are, there's a host of internal operational factors that all of us across the industry are going to have to deal with, even if it's just how you script telephone conversations regardin
componenttext: Well, I think there's a whole host of -- irrespective of what firm you are, there's a host of internal operational factors that all of us across the industry are going to have to deal with, even if it's just how you script telephone conversations regarding IRAs. So there's definitely work to be done, and I'm convinced our team is going to be able to do that. I think that this is just another indication that the model, that E*TRADE's model within the self-directed industry is going to hold up pretty well and has the right secular trends supporting its continued growth. We see continued movement to digital, continued movement to self-directed. We think those things are -- show up well for what we're trying to do.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. That's helpful. And then, just following up here on M&A thoughts, another hypothetical. But just curious how you guys would think about the utilization of stock in a deal, obviously, it's pulled back here a little bit in recent months, but i
componenttext: Okay, got it. That's helpful. And then, just following up here on M&A thoughts, another hypothetical. But just curious how you guys would think about the utilization of stock in a deal, obviously, it's pulled back here a little bit in recent months, but if you're thinking about anything on the brokerage or bank side, how would you think about that? Or are just the things that we're kind of talking about, or even thinking about, just not of the size that stock would even be necessary?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Devin, I -- it's just really hard to talk about theoreticals. And I don't want to sound like former government officials, but it's really difficult to just comment about theoreticals. So if we had anything to talk about, we'll be really clear and explain
componenttext: Devin, I -- it's just really hard to talk about theoreticals. And I don't want to sound like former government officials, but it's really difficult to just comment about theoreticals. So if we had anything to talk about, we'll be really clear and explain our rationale how we decided to fund it or anything, but we -- it's just difficult to talk theoretically.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay, no, that's fair enough. And just last on the NIM, a follow-up here again. On reinvestment rates, where are you guys seeing them right now in the securities portfolio, as you're building out a little bit further and as some are rolling off? A
componenttext: Got it. Okay, no, that's fair enough. And just last on the NIM, a follow-up here again. On reinvestment rates, where are you guys seeing them right now in the securities portfolio, as you're building out a little bit further and as some are rolling off? And within that outlook, what is implied in sec lending? Just curious kind of where you see that with the lower margin balances.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Reinvestment rate's about 175 to 200 basis point range. We've been pretty much in that range over the quarter. We're seeing a lot of volatility in rates but also seeing a lot of volatility in agency spreads. So even on the days where rates moved pretty lo
componenttext: Reinvestment rate's about 175 to 200 basis point range. We've been pretty much in that range over the quarter. We're seeing a lot of volatility in rates but also seeing a lot of volatility in agency spreads. So even on the days where rates moved pretty low, we were still able to purchase at some attractive overall spread levels. Within securities lending, securities lending did move down with margin, although it's going to ebb and flow, both with the size of the margin book as well as the amount of hard-to-borrows within the book. So even with the size of the book coming down, you can still see that we did fairly well overall in securities lending this quarter. And I think as the market more normalizes, we'll see the hard-to-borrow activity pick back up again.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Christian Bolu with Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Christian Bolu with Crdit Suisse.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, Mike, so question -- another question, unfortunately, on M&A. I hear you loud and clear on the high bar to take on credit risk. So just curious, first of all, what kind of returns you would need to take on said credit risk. And then, more broadly, w
componenttext: Paul, Mike, so question -- another question, unfortunately, on M&A. I hear you loud and clear on the high bar to take on credit risk. So just curious, first of all, what kind of returns you would need to take on said credit risk. And then, more broadly, what is the strategic rationale of even considering any current credit risk? I don't know, do you believe you have sort of competitive edge on evaluating credit? Or is there some other kind of strategic rationale that I'm missing?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, Chris, and I think we've talked about some of this in the -- at some of the public comments we made at some of the conferences. Some of the areas that we would look that have sort of wealth management and other areas within -- that fall wit
componenttext: Well, I think, Chris, and I think we've talked about some of this in the -- at some of the public comments we made at some of the conferences. Some of the areas that we would look that have sort of wealth management and other areas within -- that fall within a banking space may come with some credit assets. The return, however, that we're going to apply to any credit asset is going to be well in excess of our cost of capital in terms of putting the appropriate valuation on these businesses, given they come with considerable risk. They're therefore tangential, really, in overall strategic fit to something that -- they come along with something that has a much broader strategic fit.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. And then, pardon if I missed this one in your prepared remarks, but do you have an estimate for the impact of increased FDIC rates in the back half?
componenttext: Okay, got it. And then, pardon if I missed this one in your prepared remarks, but do you have an estimate for the impact of increased FDIC rates in the back half?

componenttextpreview: Yes. If they reach -- if the FDIC reaches its threshold amount in Q3, which our sources believe us -- lead us to believe they will, it's going to be about $1 million per quarter of increased assessment.
componenttext: Yes. If they reach -- if the FDIC reaches its threshold amount in Q3, which our sources believe us -- lead us to believe they will, it's going to be about $1 million per quarter of increased assessment.

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Bedell with Deutsche Bank.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, maybe just talk a little bit more about the DOL. And your IRA rollover business retirement assets, I think, are is close to $50 billion. I guess, first of all, how much of that is in IRAs? And then, more strategically, with the DOL rules, how does t
componenttext: Paul, maybe just talk a little bit more about the DOL. And your IRA rollover business retirement assets, I think, are is close to $50 billion. I guess, first of all, how much of that is in IRAs? And then, more strategically, with the DOL rules, how does that impact the stock plan administration business and how -- the strategy of converting those users over to your platform?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't break out what portion of retirement assets are IRA versus other. With regard to stock plan business, it shouldn't impact our opportunities of continuing to make those participants great customers of E*TRADE and, in fact, may give us some opportu
componenttext: We don't break out what portion of retirement assets are IRA versus other. With regard to stock plan business, it shouldn't impact our opportunities of continuing to make those participants great customers of E*TRADE and, in fact, may give us some opportunities to have some discussions along the way, as they may not be getting as well served by some of their other providers as a result of this.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, so you view it as an opportunity, essentially, more than something that could be burdensome?
componenttext: Okay, so you view it as an opportunity, essentially, more than something that could be burdensome?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's definitely burdensome, but I think it's an opportunity for our model relative to others.
componenttext: Well, it's definitely burdensome, but I think it's an opportunity for our model relative to others.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Okay, great. And then just in the longer-term plan of accelerating organic growth, can you talk a little bit about -- from the acquisition side, from a -- I guess, from a capability perspective, what do you think you need to accelerate that client o
componenttext: Okay. Okay, great. And then just in the longer-term plan of accelerating organic growth, can you talk a little bit about -- from the acquisition side, from a -- I guess, from a capability perspective, what do you think you need to accelerate that client organic growth? What types of -- is it is largely wealth management? Or do you feel we need more technology on like a robo-advisory capability?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we already do have a robo-advisory capability. We've had it for some time. We have a new version coming out later this year, and something I look forward to talking more about in a subsequent call. But I'd say there are several fronts for us on this
componenttext: Well, we already do have a robo-advisory capability. We've had it for some time. We have a new version coming out later this year, and something I look forward to talking more about in a subsequent call. But I'd say there are several fronts for us on this accelerating organic growth. One is you will have seen us do some significant hiring over the last year, and that's primarily across hiring more financial consultants. It also has to do with adding, along with account growth, additional customer service people so that we're providing good service and adding some professionals into the corporate services, participant experience area, where some of our nascent efforts there are actually turning out very nicely. The second is we interact with every one of our customers digitally, and you're seeing us do things to continue to improve our edge in mobile and to make our overall web experience and mobile experience the type of experience that makes people want to engage more fulsomely with us and with improving in their financial health. So it's a bit of doing a lot of little things better and continuing down the path.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Well, I can tell you, over the course of the quarter, we saw less initial activity in the early months, and it did pick up a little bit in the later months, but not meaningful enough to have an effect on the commission per trade being down $0.02 from Q4. Whether we see some of that come through this quarter or not, I think we're going to have to wait and see how things progress.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, Paul, just one quick one on the M&A or the growth side. I think, on one hand, when you look at getting through or growing through the $50 billion you mentioned in a different rate environment and maybe if the cash generation was stronger,
componenttext: Okay. And then, Paul, just one quick one on the M&A or the growth side. I think, on one hand, when you look at getting through or growing through the $50 billion you mentioned in a different rate environment and maybe if the cash generation was stronger, then you would potentially pursue that. Just wanted to get your sense on what environment that might be. And then, on the strategic side, it seems like there's a ton going on in financials in the tech area or fintech. On one hand, it seems like that's the pricier area, but on the other hand, it's obviously where the industry is going. And so I just wanted to get your thoughts on how quickly can you build something versus having to acquire something and vice versa? Is there are a lot of demand out there for a financial services company for -- or on the tech side, meaning tech firms looking at financial service firms to kind of grow in that space?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me try and take those in turn. I'd say, the jumping over the $50 billion mark is impacted by 2 things. I mean, clearly, you want to have a quantum of cash that makes it worth your while to earn on that cash. Because the costs are the same, whether you
componenttext: Let me try and take those in turn. I'd say, the jumping over the $50 billion mark is impacted by 2 things. I mean, clearly, you want to have a quantum of cash that makes it worth your while to earn on that cash. Because the costs are the same, whether you're at $51 billion or $61 billion. And the rate environment, obviously, makes it easier to jump more quickly. Just do the math. With regard to looking at fintech opportunities, I think the question for us continues to be, how quickly can we deploy something across our customer base? And would it bring incremental revenues? Would it strengthen the customer tie with our company? And so we're continuing to look. I do think the valuations make certain deals difficult, and so we evaluate that. But speed to market is important. And I'm not all that familiar, I presume some of your guys would be more familiar than I am with a lot of fintech firms looking at actually acquiring something that's going to get them nicely regulated, to the degree that I don't think they can even possibly imagine. So that'd be my way of looking at it.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good evening, and thank you for joining E*TRADE Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Joining the call today are Chief Executive Officer, Mr. Paul Idzik; and Chief Financial Officer, Mr. Michael Pizzi.Today's call may include forward-looking sta
componenttext:
Good evening, and thank you for joining E*TRADE Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Joining the call today are Chief Executive Officer, Mr. Paul Idzik; and Chief Financial Officer, Mr. Michael Pizzi.
Today's call may include forward-looking statements which reflect management's current estimates or beliefs and are subject to risks and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ materially.
During the call, the company may also discuss non-GAAP financial measures. For a reconciliation of such non-GAAP measures to the comparable GAAP figures and for a discussion of additional risks and uncertainties that may affect the future results of E*TRADE Financial, please refer to our earnings release furnished with Form 8-K and our 10-Ks, 10-Qs and other documents the company has filed with the SEC. Note that we've a of these documents are available at about.etrade.com. because material items that impacted those measures are out of our control ordered cannot be recently predicted.
[Audio Gap] call will present information as of July 21, 2016. The company disclaims any duty to update forward-looking statements made during the call. This call is being recorded, and a replay will be available via phone and webcast later this evening at about.etrade.com. No other recordings or copies of this call are authorized or may be relied upon. With that, I will now turn the call over to Mr. Idzik.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good evening, and thank you for spending some time with us. We had a productive quarter marked by a number of accomplishments in both the customer facing and financial fronts. We launched one of our most compelling offerings in recent history,
componenttext:
Thank you. Good evening, and thank you for spending some time with us. We had a productive quarter marked by a number of accomplishments in both the customer facing and financial fronts. We launched one of our most compelling offerings in recent history, we generated healthy levels of capital, while marching forward on our capital deployment initiatives, and the investment made to strengthen our platforms in infrastructure, again proved their worth as we handled the flurry of Brexit-inspired customer activity without getting onto a sticky wicket. Meanwhile, on an industry level, we managed the challenges of the revenue environment, while progressing our work related to the Department of Labor fiduciary standard. 
starting with our results. We reported net income of $133 million or $0.48 per share for the quarter. We again had a sizable benefit to the provisional line, led by a solid nonperformance and outsized recoveries. This recoveries are phenomenon which is difficult to predict, but can dramatically impact the portfolio as seasoned as ours. On the customer activity front, metrics remain healthy, largely reflecting seasonality relative to the prior quarter. Training activities declined throughout the period, but experienced a spike surrounding the courageous U.K. vote to leave the European Union, when our customers took advantage of the dip in the equity markets to the tune of $1.1 billion of net buying during the single trading day, the highest on record. The significant attention we placed on strengthening our infrastructure over the past several years enabled our platforms to handle these elevated volumes with room to spare. For the entire quarter, a record 17% of DARTs were executive by our mobile platforms. And July to date, DARTs are currently tracking down 1% from June.
Margin balances, which had slowed edged down through our Q1, ended the second quarter up at $6.8 billion. The majority of the $0.5 billion increase was a Brexit bolstered spike, so the quarter's average was lower at $6.5 billion. In July to date, balances have tapered to $6.4 billion.
We had a 23,000 net new accounts in Q2, down from Q1 solid 45,000. Adjusted new accounts in last year's 25,000. Our attrition rate of 8.3% remain encouraging for the quarter, while an increase from a near-record adjusted 7.3% in the prior quarter, a decrease from adjusted 8.7% a year ago. We also attracted $1.6 billion in net new brokerage assets, reflecting our strongest Q2 in several years, but down sequentially on typical tax-related outflows in April. We made meaningful enhancement to the customer experience this quarter. On the product front, portfolio our robust solution is the most important new product launch in some time. While still very early days from our June launch, we are pleased with the adoptions, having amassed more than 100 million of assets under management in the program, including legacy managed account balances converted upon launch. The offering stands out in a few ways. First, it provides our customer the option of combining active and passive management, a new concept for auto investing space, which has relied on passive-only portfolios. Second, it falls between our pure digital and managed account solutions, delivering a best in class digital experience combined with access to financial consultants when customers have questions and want to discuss the portfolio selected by the online tool. Third, at circa 1% below cash allocation, means customer put to work for them through there investments, while keeping just enough cash to rebalance and service the portfolio as necessary. And last, consistent with our unbiased approach to providing our customers with the solution right for their own needs, we have no proprietary products within our model portfolios. So the investments available to customers are selected to be the best for each particular portfolio construction, and not just the best to happen to carry our name. Importantly, the solution serves longer-term retirement investing and savings dollars, so it is an important component of our ongoing efforts to increase share wallet among our existing customer base. Additionally, we found that as customers and prospects are navigating the portfolio experience, they are also looking at other offerings leading to increased activity and self-directed account openings. 
over to our corporate services channels, we are in a midst of rolling out a completely redesigned stock plan experience. We have long had an edge in this business because of our top rated platform, Equity Edge Online. However, over the part 3 years, we have been acutely focused on further improving both the B2B and B2C elements of this channel. This rollout presents planned participants with a more streamlined, intuitive and engaging experience. We always strive to surprise and delight our customers when it comes to stock plan participants getting the digital experience right is essential. We understand deeply that these participants are not your typical investor, often joining us with financial knowledge of less developed than what we find with mainstream E*TRADE  customers. Further, stock plan benefits are complicated, so the more we can do educate and engage these participants, the more they value to this component of their compensation, and thus appropriately their employer for providing it. This is no small responsibility, and what we take extremely seriously.
In terms of industry accolades, we recognized by this quarter and by any overview of online brokers, earning high marks in tools and ease of use, as well as first place for mobile, a platform which is increasingly important to our customers and where we frequently stand out from the crowd. 
Expenses for the quarter were $295 million, down $17 million from Q1, primary due to advertising, driving our adjusted operating margin, which excludes provision to 38% from 34%. In the face of a progressively challenging interest-rate environment, we remain committed to keeping our expenses appropriately sized and continue to expect a 37% adjusted operative margin for the full year, factors.
On the capital front, we continue to execute on both of our deployment initiatives, putting a $151 million to work, repurchasing our common stock, ending the quarter nearly 2/3 the way through our $800 million program, and continuing to grow the balance sheet, ending the quarter at $49.2 billion, closely approaching our target of $49.5 billion. And form what's next, we continue to dedicate a lot of time and energy to this question, considering share repurchase beyond their current program, evaluating growth through acquisition and examining balance sheet growth beyond our current target. Regarding that final point, we have been very clear that in order to justify the compliance costs and achieve appropriate returns on capital, we need combination of high interest rates and a more sizable quantum of deposits to allow us to pounce constantly over the $50 billion threshold. Today with interest rate unlike to rise in the near-term and our current level of available off-balance sheet deposits at about $2 billion, we have planned to dance below the line as crossing would equate to more of a tiptoe than the pounce. However, with industry form making money markets fund to suboptimal sweep vehicle for customers, the team is working to convert approximately $4 billion or substantially all of our money market funds into our cash program, thus increasing about potential balance sheet size to above $55 billion. While there is still boxes to check, we already have regulatory approval and we to complete this conversion in September. With that move, we anticipate crossing $50 billion in the first half of next year. Mr.  will provide update on the particulars and the cost to conduct the pounds. 
Moving on to the DOL standards, we made significant headway this quarter working through this overreaching rule, which is proved rather in nature and shrouded with ambiguity. I'm pleased to report that we completed much of the analysis and are moving on to implementation. This was no small task, and I commend the internal team that worked diligently to get us where we are. We do anticipate additional cost as we work through the implementation phase, including those related to third-party assistance, industry experts and council, digital enhancements to adopt the rule in our platform and increased legal and compliance costs. Importantly, we are well-positioned to be fully compliant within the DOL state of implementation days, and these expenses are included within our target operating margin for the year.
And now, a note on A couple of weeks ago, we further strengthened our board with addition of Kevin Kevin's extensive background in financial services at our Board, which now stands at 12 members. Kevin spent more than 30 years in the industry, including the last 8 years as CEO of Bank Corp. In addition, he has experience in a number of boards, both public companies, insurable organizations. We are fortunate to benefit from his insights, particularly as we position the company to cross $50 billion. 
So in summary, it's been a solid first half of the year, and while I'm pleased with where we stand, we have plenty to accomplish on capital deployment, growth, expense management and our primary mandate, which is to serve the retail investor. On all fronts, I'm excited about what's in store for the remainder of this year. And with that, I will turn it over to our CFO, Mr. Pizzi.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mr. Idzik. For the quarter, we reported net income of a $133 million or $0.48 per share. This compares to adjusted net income of $122 million or $0.43 per share in the prior quarter, which excludes the $31 million income tax benefit. It also co
componenttext:
Thank you, Mr. Idzik. For the quarter, we reported net income of a $133 million or $0.48 per share. This compares to adjusted net income of $122 million or $0.43 per share in the prior quarter, which excludes the $31 million income tax benefit. It also compares to adjusted net income of $72 million or $0.25 per share in the year-ago quarter, which excludes the $220 million income tax benefit. Revenues for the quarter were $474 million, up $2 million from the prior quarter, largely related to higher yields on customer assets held by third parties, and up $45 million from the year-ago quarter, largely attributable to the benefits from our wholesale termination and the Fed rate hike. Net interest income was $286 million for the quarter, down $1 million from the prior quarter as a 17 basis point reduction in net interest margin was mostly offset by a $2.5 billion larger average balance sheet. Our net interest margin of 264 basis points decreased as we put money to work growing our balance sheet in rate environment and as average margin balances contracted. The rate environment is certainly impacting us, with our average reinvestment rate now in the range of 150 to 175 basis points. We continue to expect our full year net interest margin to be 260 to 265 basis points, with the back half of the year in the mid-250s. This also assumes no change in the Fed fund's rate and that margin balances remain constant with their current level. Commission, fees and service charges and other revenue were $178 million, up $3 million from the prior quarter and up $11 million versus the year-ago quarter. Compared to Q1, commissions revenue decreased $1 million as lower trading activity was offset by higher average commission, per trade, which increased $0.18 to $10.82, driven by a higher portion of stock plan customer traits and more options contracts per trade. Relative to the year-ago quarter, commissions revenue increased $3 million on higher trading activity, partially offset by a $0.14 decline in the average commission related to higher mix of active traders. Fees and service charges revenue increased relative to both the prior quarter and the year-ago quarter, primarily attributable to the higher fees and higher yield on customer assets held by third parties. This quarter, the average yield on those assets was 41 basis points, up 11 basis points from Q1. As Paul mentioned, we expect to convert approximately $4 billion of money market funds into our cash program in September. Securities and other gains were $10 million, flat with the prior quarter. For the full year, we expect gains to be at the high-end of our $30 million to $40 million range. Noninterest expenses for the quarter was $295 million, down $17 million sequentially, with the biggest driver being a seasonal decline in marketing. Expenses were about $7 million below our expectations due to a further up marketing in response to the environment and a small benefit running through expense. Our adjusted operating margin for the quarter was 38%, up from 34% in Q1 as revenues were slightly and expenses decreased significantly. Our commitment to manage to an operating margin requires us to our expense closely. And while our operating margin improved, there is much more work to do as our revenue continues to face environment headwinds from low interest rates.
With the rational expense structure already in place and a discipline-to-marketing spend, we are committed to regularly productivity, where output can be achieved with resources. While this effort is ongoing, the current revenue environment makes our commitment to respond all the more important, and we're steadfast in supporting our operating margin target of 37% for the year. 
Moving on to the provision line. We recorded a benefit of $35 million for the quarter, once again better-than-expected. Net charge-offs were positive at $6 million of recoveries, contributed to the $29 million reduction in the allowance of $293 million. While the overall portfolio reduced by $300 million or 6%, ending the quarter at $4.4 billion.
Recoveries continue to be a significant factor propelling provision benefit. As we have said in the past, recoveries in the recapture previously charge-offs loans are exceptionally difficult to predict and can meaningfully swing our results. We also continue to benefit from better-than-expected performance of high risk loans that have been  reserved for the full life of loan. This quarter, we had a relatively small amount of new conversions at just about 50 million. Overall, the performance of conversions remains consistent, with an average rate of approximately 12%, about twice that of a nonconverting loan. At this point, about $0.7 million or 45% of the HELOC portfolio has yet to convert. Nearly all of those occur over the next 3 quarters, with a fairly even distribution across each. So while we are pleased with the performance of HELOC conversions to date, we have a sizable amount left to convert, and we do expect losses to increase as a result. We believe we are adequately reserved for the losses and thus expect provision to be 0 the remainder of the year, with the caveat that many of the variables I just covered, can have a meaningful impact on the provision result. 
Moving on to capital. We distributed $190 million up to the during the quarter comprising the following. $85 million from the bank, which is below Q1 net income of $108 million, as we utilized capital to fund balance sheet growth, and $102 million from the brokers, comprising $27 million from the introducing broker and $75 million from the clearing broker. In Q3, we expect total dividend to the parent of roughly $125 million, which includes $40 million from the banks, again below current quarter bank net income of $106 million, as we will use capital in Q3 for balance sheet growth. $57 million from the introducing broker and $28 million from a clearing broker. As with last quarter's move, capital is being released from have as it have reduced.
We're currently in the process of merging our 2 broker-dealers. So starting in the fourth quarter, we will have a single brokerage entity to distribute capital to the parent. Without going into too much detail, the entities were separated about 15 years ago for operational reasons that are no longer relevant. The combined entity will streamline our organizational structure and regulatory oversight. In terms of capital, we expect future distributions to be consistent with that historically distributed out of the introducing broker. 
So on to capital generation. We ended the quarter with strong measures at both the bank and parent. The bank's leverage issue ended the quarter at 8.2%, above our current 8% target. Keep in mind, that we intend to seek approval to lower this targets to 7.5% early next year. At the parent, we ended the quarter with Tier 1 leverage issue of 7.5%, above our minimum of 7%. And the other metric by which we measure available capital cash ended the quarter at $523 million, well above our minimum of $100 million or 2 years of debt service coverage. So we are in a strong position to continue deploying capital. 
We remain active on that front in the quarter, repurchasing a 151 million of our common stock and growing the balance sheet by $1.3 billion. We have now completed more than $500 million of our 800 million share repurchase program, having repurchase 5.9 million shares during the quarter and 20.6 million over the course of the entire programs at an average price of $24.34. On balance sheet growth, we ended the quarter at $49.2 billion, just shy of our current target of $49.5 billion of consolidated assets. To expand on Paul's comments regarding our plans to exceed $50 billion in the first half of next year, after converting the money market funds to our program in September, on a pro forma basis, we have approximately $6 billion of deposits readily available to bring on balance sheet, assuming no organic growth between now and then. That amount puts crossing $50 billion squarely within economic reach. From a capital perspective, we anticipate funding this growth through earnings and a lower bank Tier 1 leverage threshold. There are host of reporting changes and filing we will enjoy with our increased size, all of which we're currently digging through. We will provide updates on these on future calls.
With respect to incurring the expenses related to crossings, it is still too early to assign precision to timing, however, our rought estimates assume $50 million related to the build-out, with around $5 million incurred in the second half of this year and the remainder evenly spend in 2017 and 2018, and the running cost of approximately $15 million per year will start to occur in 2017 with a full run rate in 2018. Needless to say, with the right amount of deposit at our disposables, the returns are quite campaigning and we're excited to unshackle our growth. And with that operator, we will open the call for questions.

However, the crossovers is highly sensitive to reinvestment rate assumptions. I'm just wondering, given the range you have given in terms of the reinvestment yields, if you stay at the lower end of that range at a 150 basis points, does that impact at all the timing of your decision?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not really. I mean in that range of 150 to 175, I mean, I think we have to have some confidence that we're not going to continually go lower than we have seen here post Brexit, is hopefully -- is going to hold the sort of the lower range in yields. If we'
componenttext: Not really. I mean in that range of 150 to 175, I mean, I think we have to have some confidence that we're not going to continually go lower than we have seen here post Brexit, is hopefully -- is going to hold the sort of the lower range in yields. If we're within that range, I mean, you can do the math at a 7.5 capital hold. What that really equates to is a spread and what the incremental return that's generating on the marginal capital. We feel that's a pretty reasonable use of capital at that level. And that's the right decision to begin the work and to begin incurring the cost to support levels greater than 50.

Putting things on the balance sheet is good long-term attractive growth, good for our shareholders. If you were to find an acquisition that was attractive that we thought was good for the shareholders, we do that. And no, I don't believe either of these things we're talking about would make us less attractive to a potential acquirer.

And Mike, technical one on the balance sheet, but looking beyond 2016, one of the questions we most often is, if we were to assume a statical yield curve, and just looking at maturity your security book and assuming a steady pace of loan runoff, what will be your reasonable expectation for NIM compression beyond 2016, recognizing that they are going to be some investment headwinds less equal?

componenttext: Yes. I mean, you can take a look at the securities yields, and compare them to kind of where we are at the margin, which is that 150 to 175. Keep in mind, that's on a fairly depressed yield curve as we ended the quarter. That was 1.75 to 2 in the prior period. So hopefully we get some degree in normalization of these post-Brexit But if we don't, I mean, you can model it over the average life of the securities portfolio to be coming down in line with the life of the portfolio that we're going to recycle into the marginal rate on the securities book, keeping in mind that both stock lending and margin will continue to support higher spread than just with the securities generating on the margin.

componenttext: Well, as you can see, the amount of corporate cash we have available today and the buffer we have over 7 today, is almost enough to complete the buyback program. Given the timing to say, sort of first half of next year to break 50, with the bank possibly moving down from 8 to 7.5, we can fund the organic balance, some of that organic balance sheet roughly about half with the decline in the ratio at the bank. The rest will have to come through retained earnings at the bank. And then that will support also the capital ratio at the parent level. So we have the ability to complete the current buyback program and still breakthrough 50 in the timing if we were able to achieve the within our capital plan.

componenttext: Well, I mean, if you -- I mean if you start to go materially below the 150 to 175 range, you start talking about maybe 1% gross, so netting the money on buffet. componenttext: Sure. So it's a bit to early to tell on range. But it's a lot of things where we have. componenttext: The loans are -- the securities portfolio is not a legacy portfolio. There's nothing legacy in it at this point. It's largely just a reinvestment of our agency securities book. So there are higher yields in there that are from past investments and higher rate cycles. But it's in line really with our liability -- with the average life of our liability duration, which we put in of a kind of high 3s, mid-4s area.

componenttext: Well, if you think about it this way, if we're successful in getting from 8 to 7.5, that's going to be about a $180 million, a capital free-up. componenttext: Well, I think if I understand your question correctly. Overall, we're going to have this large amount of $6 billion tt we're going to convert. Organic growth continues to grow with every account as the FDIC product is the marginal cash product for every -- just about every customer today. So whether they are coming from stock plan or whether they are coming from organic channels, we continue to grow that cash. With roughly about 17% of an account in the form of cash, cash will grow as we grow the total number of accounts. Cash does move quarter-to-quarter and it does move up on down, but overall, it's been a growing trend as we grow our business.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, first of all, we're differentiating the product mainly in 3 ways. One, it's the only product out there that offers both active and just passive management to the client to chose which one they want. Secondly, with only 1% cash requirement, putting m
componenttext: Mike, first of all, we're differentiating the product mainly in 3 ways. One, it's the only product out there that offers both active and just passive management to the client to chose which one they want. Secondly, with only 1% cash requirement, putting more of each dollar of investment to work for our customers. I mean, that's a very nice value proposition. And third, unlike people who work at Bank of America or anyone else on this call, many of our customer do need help with their account and what's happening in tax season. And so, rather than some of the pure plays, we're also there for them when they want to call us to talk about what's happening. Interestingly, as we've started this product, which was sadly lacking from our of products. we're seeing people come, look at the site, and in addition to looking at finding out that they're also opening sometimes in conjunction with or sometimes instead of opening self direct to the account. So anything we can do to get new customers and existing customers to really think about what's the right way to position their portfolio, we think it's just an important service to provide, and it's going to pay off well for us in the future.
