componenttext: Okay, okay. And I'll just do one follow-up here. But I guess, the question is, Rodger, you've laid out the 2% to 3% growth target and over an 18- to 24-month period, we're not going to talk directly about any acquisition or M&A activity. But I guess, I would like to know what happens if you don't beat that 2% to 3% hurdle in that time period.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks for the question. This is a very important question, a lot of people I'm sure are thinking of the same question. So thanks for asking it. In terms of my response, let me give you a little bit about of context and I may answer this question sl
componenttext: Okay, thanks for the question. This is a very important question, a lot of people I'm sure are thinking of the same question. So thanks for asking it. In terms of my response, let me give you a little bit about of context and I may answer this question slightly longer than normal. We picked the 18 to 24 months because, I think, we all thought that was an adequate time to really show the Board and to show shareholders that we could get along the growth map that we described at the conference. Actually we talked, Rich, about organic growth and may well be that an inorganic opportunity comes along during that process. But just an 18- to 24-month period we thought it was adequate time to show we could deliver. And I think from a Board point of view, we need to feel very, very comfortable and we can continue to add shareholder value. Now let's go to the potential outcomes and to the heart of your question, let's take a negative outlook first. What happens if we can't deliver? We conclude that we cannot get to those kind of growth rates and that we can't therefore, continue to deliver shareholder value. And I think there are a series of options, more options than one might think. The one which obviously goes through is the sale. But maybe other options in terms of partnerships, we have weakness we know them in our business model. If we can not treat them ourselves, it may be feasible to correct them with partners. But, clearly, a sale, partnerships, there are series of different scenarios which crop up. The only thing I would say, which is definitive is that the Board will not allow loss of value. Now having said that, I looked at the positive side, let's assume we do deliver, which -- because it goes both ways and I recognize your question, what if we don't. Let's assume we do deliver, we actually at this moment in time really consider that is possible, wherein, just speaking to myself, I don't know if I speak for Karl and Mike and Brett, we're very, very impressed with what's happening here. And there's a real commitment to deliver on the growth drivers that we talked about at the conference. There are a body of people at this rate who really want to succeed and really want to see the company succeed. So even though we're talking about what happens if we don't succeed, I think it's not out of order to say that we believe very strongly we will. And having said that, I'm sure we have in the phone audience who would say that's just words, but it gives you a little reminder. I came on this Board at the beginning of 2012, along with my Board colleague [indiscernible] from Charles Schwab. And I remember at that time, Rich, a lot of doubts are being expressed on whether we could deliver and what I characterize as a low-hanging fruit, but it really was tough to achieve. A lot of doubt are being expressed then, could we refinance that debt, could we improve our funding cost, was our portfolio going to drown, what's going to happen to the HELOCs? Will we get the benefit of our DTA given the fact that the DTA if you're not earning, how the hell can you use your DTA. And so I think that, that, by the way, what was my interpretation of body language and these share price stock, it was somewhere in the middle or low single-digits. And yet 4.5 years later, here we are. So I think at that time it was real doubt as to where the management team could deliver. Rich, I think we put our money where our mouth was and delivered good credit to them. So now, where do we go with the next 34 months, we will, as a Board, seriously consider how we're doing and we'll consider options. So this is not usually out on anything, we will consider all options, we understand what our role is and the value we have to deliver. But I will say again, given the kind of people we got it at E*TRADE, I think we believe that you could achieve the value goals we will set. And we clearly that will mean an improvement in shareholder value as we go forward. So I'll give you a long run around, Rich, so the question you asked. But I hope it illustrates what our thinking is.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Steven Chubak from Nomura.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Steven Chubak from Nomura.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Rodger, I really appreciated all the detail you provided and to the last question. I'm going to take a slightly different take here. As we think about some of the best avenues for creating long-term shareholder value and you certainly framed it in that
componenttext: So Rodger, I really appreciated all the detail you provided and to the last question. I'm going to take a slightly different take here. As we think about some of the best avenues for creating long-term shareholder value and you certainly framed it in that context in terms of how you're thinking about the long-term brokerage strategy, can you articulate specifically how improving the organic growth profile by 200 to 300 basis points would justify operating on a stand-alone basis and is there maybe a better alternative or more accretive path versus a combination of one of your largest brokerage peers?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's a very, very good question. I can't tell you what the precise algorithm is 2% to 3% equals an accessible level of shareholder appreciation. But what I would say that, that level of growth gets us to markets down this because that's how far we'r
componenttext: Well, it's a very, very good question. I can't tell you what the precise algorithm is 2% to 3% equals an accessible level of shareholder appreciation. But what I would say that, that level of growth gets us to markets down this because that's how far we're behind. It will run through assuming we acquired the types of accounts and the types of trading activity and the types of margin of all things obviously, you're very well aware of. And we have absorbed this huge amount of fixed expense in the company over the course of the last 2 or 3 years. Remember, seeing some of the prepared remarks addressed the fact that we really have fixed the operating foundation I think are the words we used in the company. So I think the reality is that level of growth will get us to a rate of return, which I think is comparable to our competitors in terms of the organic growth. We did say 18 to 24 months, but the world doesn't end at the end of 24 months. I think we'll continuously be reviewing that. We do have weaknesses in the business model, we recognize that. We would be happier we have developed the RAA channel, we don't have it. Clearly, if we could have one acquired inorganically or at a sensible price, I think it will make us more competitive. But I think the 2% to 3% will deliver comparable rates of increase return. I think it also is a rallying cry for all the troops in the company to pursue what has to be done in order for us to be as competitive as we are. But having said all of the above, it's really never ending, it's a continuous evolution and we're going to have to keep evolving the company as we go forward.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe switching gears for a moment, but I guess, focusing on the strategy but thinking about things in the M&A context. I recognize that you're not going to speak about recent announcements from some of your competitors, but just looking at the broader M&
componenttext: Maybe switching gears for a moment, but I guess, focusing on the strategy but thinking about things in the M&A context. I recognize that you're not going to speak about recent announcements from some of your competitors, but just looking at the broader M&A landscape and opportunity, I'm wondering whether you would consider large-scale acquisitions during this current 18 -- to 24-month time window. It sounded like you might consider some opportunities, may be enhanced capabilities, just speaking specifically by any large-scale opportunities given that you're still working through an OptionsHouse integration and could that impact your appetite or the willingness to acquire any other properties?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So -- it's Karl. So looking at sort of where we are right now and what's happening in the landscape, just keeping in mind, the management team and the Board of this company is always focused on what's going to drive the company value, more importantly, wh
componenttext: So -- it's Karl. So looking at sort of where we are right now and what's happening in the landscape, just keeping in mind, the management team and the Board of this company is always focused on what's going to drive the company value, more importantly, what's going to drive shareholder value. So if there acquisitions out there, whether it be a scale acquisition or if it were to be a product extension or a channel that we don't have right now that could drive revenue. And when we looked as methodically as we do anything that we look at, if it were to drive shareholder value, we definitely would be interested, right? But we take a look at it through the same lens, we communicate with our regulators, make sure that everybody was teed up on it before we move on it. We're very disciplined in our approach to things, we have to be.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And, Steve, I'll just add a comment to that. We're always going to look at acquisitions, maybe just because we're nosy and we want to know what the competition's out to, or it may well be because it represents a real opportunity to grow scale or enhance o
componenttext: And, Steve, I'll just add a comment to that. We're always going to look at acquisitions, maybe just because we're nosy and we want to know what the competition's out to, or it may well be because it represents a real opportunity to grow scale or enhance our business model, which is the driving issue. So we're always going to look.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Okay. And then just one more modeling question for me if I may. And maybe suited for Mike. You mentioned that the servicing charges in fee line, there are various puts and takes so you have to consider the OptionsHouse contribution. But presuma
componenttext: All right. Okay. And then just one more modeling question for me if I may. And maybe suited for Mike. You mentioned that the servicing charges in fee line, there are various puts and takes so you have to consider the OptionsHouse contribution. But presumably, there are some benefit from off balance sheet deposits, which will go away. How should we think about the run rate for that line item once all of the off balance sheet deposits have been swept to the bag and you have the full contribution from OptionsHouse?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Once you have all the -- if you look at the amount of off-balance sheet assets, $14 billion is predominantly now all on a sweep program. That's going to shift down about $3 billion of that will remain off balance sheet. The rate they came in this qua
componenttext: Yes. Once you have all the -- if you look at the amount of off-balance sheet assets, $14 billion is predominantly now all on a sweep program. That's going to shift down about $3 billion of that will remain off balance sheet. The rate they came in this quarter is really market determined. And so that market determined rate will move with benchmark rates, both LIBOR and Fed funds rate.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from the line of Chris Harris with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Next question comes from the line of Chris Harris with Wells Fargo.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question on your margins. I appreciate the guidance for the fourth quarter, but there's a lot of moving parts as we get into 2017. So any comment or anything else you guys can kind of guide as to how should we be thinking about trajectory of your margin
componenttext: A question on your margins. I appreciate the guidance for the fourth quarter, but there's a lot of moving parts as we get into 2017. So any comment or anything else you guys can kind of guide as to how should we be thinking about trajectory of your margins as we get into next year?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Chris. There is a lot of moving parts and we're going to have a lot more to give you a firm guidance on when we complete our budget and capital planning process, which we're in the midst of now. So we will give you a firm target. Right now, with the
componenttext: Yes, Chris. There is a lot of moving parts and we're going to have a lot more to give you a firm guidance on when we complete our budget and capital planning process, which we're in the midst of now. So we will give you a firm target. Right now, with the integration of OptionsHouse, you can see that the OptionsHouse margin may be lower than ours is driving the Q4 margin down a bit on an adjusted basis. We think that as the synergies come online, the operating margin improvement from the acquisition will come through. And we should be operating next year to comparable operating margins to this year, but we'll be back with more specificity on that at the next call.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then one quick other question here on expenses. The run rate savings you guys have talked about $21 million. Can you expand a little bit on where that came from? Is any of that in client-facing positions? And is that sufficient enough to
componenttext: Okay, great. And then one quick other question here on expenses. The run rate savings you guys have talked about $21 million. Can you expand a little bit on where that came from? Is any of that in client-facing positions? And is that sufficient enough to cover your growth expenses for next year?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the $21 million really came from the elimination of the positions that I talked in the prepared remarks. And just looking at our organization and really getting alignment throughout, particularly on the brokerage side itself, making sure that the right
componenttext: So the $21 million really came from the elimination of the positions that I talked in the prepared remarks. And just looking at our organization and really getting alignment throughout, particularly on the brokerage side itself, making sure that the right pieces are all under Mike so that we can get the perfect execution and deliver on some of the growth that we've talked about. We don't plan on that 21 that came out funding growth or otherwise. If we are going to continue to grow and continue to find new projects to invest in, we'll have to find that within the business. And as Mike just laid out, we plan to sort of stay within the out margins that we've been at now couple, we said that a couple of times, now happy to repeat it. Nothing was customer facing, right? We don't intend to impact the customer that way. These are really just looking through and garnering efficiencies gotten the right people and the right places to do that job.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from the line of Conor Fitzgerald with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Next question comes from the line of Conor Fitzgerald with Goldman Sachs.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rodger, maybe just to start with you. I think you talked about you felt that there was a lack of emphasis on growth and then it came out short versus the Board expectations. Can you give us a little more color on where exactly you felt the strategy fell s
componenttext: Rodger, maybe just to start with you. I think you talked about you felt that there was a lack of emphasis on growth and then it came out short versus the Board expectations. Can you give us a little more color on where exactly you felt the strategy fell short? And kind of what gives you confidence that the new management team can execute on those targets throughout?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Conor. A good question. I think we all feel that our marketing aggressiveness has been diminished over the course of the last few years. I don't think we're being generating the prospects and the new accounts at a rate which is commensurate either w
componenttext: Sure, Conor. A good question. I think we all feel that our marketing aggressiveness has been diminished over the course of the last few years. I don't think we're being generating the prospects and the new accounts at a rate which is commensurate either what we were spending or what we've achieved in the past. So without wishing to watch [indiscernible] any in public, I think our view would be that we can make material progress in our marketing endeavors. And that I think was a relatively -- that I would say, Conor, is one of the most dominant factor. We, as a company, as you're well aware, have the distractions over the last 5 or 6 years, maybe that takes some of the emphasis off. But I think we have dropped the ball to a degree. And personally, think we've taken -- as we are to great credit for the fact that we have really fixed the foundations of the company as per my prepared remarks. And then we've also generated the kind of financial returns, which I alluded to earlier when I said I think there were doubts we could do it. I think all credit to Michael Pizzi and his predecessor, [indiscernible], and others that they've really delivered. I think during that phase, we may have taken our eye off some of the marketing endeavors than we thought that financial success was ending on right as opposed to making means and an end. I think we need to -- as you will note over the course of next few months, we need to become much more aggressive in that space. And that's why I am personally optimistic that we can make a progress there.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And when you talk about your marketing efforts falling short, would you consider sacrificing margins in the near term to drive growth longer-term?
componenttext: And when you talk about your marketing efforts falling short, would you consider sacrificing margins in the near term to drive growth longer-term?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, you could say would always consider. In fact, it was going throughout materially through the value of the company, I think the answer is yes. Do I think it's likely to happen, which I think is more personal question is no. There's been an opportunit
componenttext: Well, you could say would always consider. In fact, it was going throughout materially through the value of the company, I think the answer is yes. Do I think it's likely to happen, which I think is more personal question is no. There's been an opportunity at the moment present themselves. But we're open to it. We were open and the Board perspective, the senior management perspective is we want to see the company grow. We use that word grow and growth, whether at the Barclays conference or no, but we want to see the company grow. And so if there's justification for significant investment in the short term because we cannot only drive share and growth but it has tangible financial value. I mean, we're not going to add accounts for the sake of it. But we think drive tangible financial value, we would, we would invest. But again, my only comment at the moment, I don't think we see that opportunity. I don't know, Karl, if you'd like to comment on that.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think that's right. I think the way you sort of laid out where we are right now on the brokerage and the amount that we've invested previously in our foundational efforts, we have to do that. It's necessary that we had to take care and we have to pu
componenttext: No, I think that's right. I think the way you sort of laid out where we are right now on the brokerage and the amount that we've invested previously in our foundational efforts, we have to do that. It's necessary that we had to take care and we have to put ourselves back in a place that we can get the operational flexibility that we now have. And the way I look at it, that same low-hanging fruit that we had in the financial side of the house and the balance sheet, we actually have a lot of opportunities on the brokerage side, right? We're very focused on risk and second lines of the fence and getting that all cleaned up. And I think we now have an opportunity. But my own humble opinion is we're not going to sacrifice in terms of changing our of out margin or eating into the good things that we've already done for short-term wins. So it would have to be long-term value base in order for us to invest in it.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And Mike, just 1 cleanup question for you. The operating margin of 35% for the fourth quarter, does that include any integration expenses? And if I kind of back out the severance and integration charges you guys are taking 3 and 4Q, does y
componenttext: That's helpful. And Mike, just 1 cleanup question for you. The operating margin of 35% for the fourth quarter, does that include any integration expenses? And if I kind of back out the severance and integration charges you guys are taking 3 and 4Q, does your 38% margin target for the year still hold?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So for next quarter, the 35% includes any planned integration expense, as well as having OptionsHouse in the items for our full quarter. Now keep in mind, we are in the midst of integration and there are things that are planned for next year that if
componenttext: Yes. So for next quarter, the 35% includes any planned integration expense, as well as having OptionsHouse in the items for our full quarter. Now keep in mind, we are in the midst of integration and there are things that are planned for next year that if we move faster, that may move some in the fourth quarter. Right now though, that is the plan. So that's information that we have. In terms of the year, if you look at toward the onetime items, they're pushing our adjusted operating margin down in the period to 34% by about 6 percentage points. So if you take those onetime items out, which are about $31 million or $0.07 throughout and then take the 35, you'll see that we're coming in on target.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Mike Carrier with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Mike Carrier with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just a question on the expense outlook. So if I look at this quarter, I think on a clean basis you're at 2 92. I guess, first, I just wanted to understand the $21 million that you took out in the quarter, is that sort of in the run rate? Or is there ki
componenttext: So just a question on the expense outlook. So if I look at this quarter, I think on a clean basis you're at 2 92. I guess, first, I just wanted to understand the $21 million that you took out in the quarter, is that sort of in the run rate? Or is there kind of a full quarter in it to see? And then when you guys look at it and this is more into '17, when you look at it in terms of what you include on the expenses or those target margins, are you including the OptionsHouse, the integration cost, the bank cost? Or is any of that going to be like restructuring or new acquisition-related so we understand kind of what you're looking at what you're talking about margin?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the costs for this quarter came in more towards the back-end of the quarter over all. So from a run rate perspective, you probably see it pick up a bit. Now keep in mind, when we look at next quarter, we will have options -- we get OptionsHouse in
componenttext: Yes. So the costs for this quarter came in more towards the back-end of the quarter over all. So from a run rate perspective, you probably see it pick up a bit. Now keep in mind, when we look at next quarter, we will have options -- we get OptionsHouse in the income statement for 15 days this quarter, it will begin for a full quarter. So that will affect some of those expenses. We're also starting to see some of the commitment that we made on the risk work to get through the $50 billion barrier. Some of those investments are coming through as well. So that's why we're giving you an operating margin target not specific expense guidance. Looking into next year, we think that we would like to give you a target on the January call that will encompass all expected and planned expenses that would include the CCAR expenses from the regulatory build-out expenses for that as well as all of the integration expenses of OptionsHouse.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. And then maybe just on the strategic side. You guys talk a lot about the brokerage business, yet on the other side, you're growing the bank, you're breaking through the $50 billion. Just from a strategic standpoint, given the focus and the f
componenttext: Okay, got it. And then maybe just on the strategic side. You guys talk a lot about the brokerage business, yet on the other side, you're growing the bank, you're breaking through the $50 billion. Just from a strategic standpoint, given the focus and the focus on the brokerage growth, do you think that limits you, you in terms of your options out there, whether it's on the acquisition side, with the regulators or is it okay, meaning you go down that path and still have the kind of full flexibility on the brokerage part of the business?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I don't look at -- I look at it as we have to grow the brokerage, right? It's who we are, it's our roots where our retail brokerage and that's sort of what we do every day. And the organizational alignment, that added OptionsHouse, some of the cap
componenttext: Yes. So I don't look at -- I look at it as we have to grow the brokerage, right? It's who we are, it's our roots where our retail brokerage and that's sort of what we do every day. And the organizational alignment, that added OptionsHouse, some of the capabilities that we do for us things we've done toward that end. Growing the balance sheet and taking the bank up over 50 as long as we do it smartly as we have done around here, will not lead to any additional constraints on other things. I mean, Mike Pizzi can talk to you a little bit about capital and some other pieces. But [indiscernible] have always been at the bank adds quite a bit of power to our returns. Mike, I don't [indiscernible] if you want to add capital side limitations.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think that the decision around the balance sheet creates any limitation and flexibility. It's going to be a lot of work. We've been organizing around that, building our plans accordingly. And we began to make some progress in all of those key
componenttext: No, I don't think that the decision around the balance sheet creates any limitation and flexibility. It's going to be a lot of work. We've been organizing around that, building our plans accordingly. And we began to make some progress in all of those key areas. But I don't think when there's any flexibility and what we're trying to achieve in the growth of the core business.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Michael with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Michael with Morgan Stanley.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just curious as you're thinking about accelerated growth here. If you could just talk a little bit how you're using customer data and analytics today to improve your customer acquisition, drive greater engagement and retention? And just longer term, how y
componenttext: Just curious as you're thinking about accelerated growth here. If you could just talk a little bit how you're using customer data and analytics today to improve your customer acquisition, drive greater engagement and retention? And just longer term, how you're thinking about the opportunity set from that?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'd rather approach it from the opportunities perspective because quite honestly, I think we can do a much better job of using data particularly in our marketing efforts and being more direct and sort of smarter in that we have with our customers and p
componenttext: So I'd rather approach it from the opportunities perspective because quite honestly, I think we can do a much better job of using data particularly in our marketing efforts and being more direct and sort of smarter in that we have with our customers and prospects every day. So that is something that we are focused on. We just gone through a bit of a restructuring in that organization as well. So more to follow, but we will be using data more smartly in the future.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is there anything else on the expense side as you're thinking about that with the attitude to run rate in order to get there that gets flushed out in terms of what specifically this may consist of in terms of trying to monetize that opportunity set?
componenttext: Is there anything else on the expense side as you're thinking about that with the attitude to run rate in order to get there that gets flushed out in terms of what specifically this may consist of in terms of trying to monetize that opportunity set?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. We look forward. We're doing a lot of our planning processes right now. I think everything is going to be within that operating margin framework.
componenttext: No. We look forward. We're doing a lot of our planning processes right now. I think everything is going to be within that operating margin framework.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: One last one here on the managed accounts, I think you mentioned targeting about $6 billion or so in managed accounts. Just curious how you're thinking about what sort of those products would be is it just growing the Robo that you launched recently? Is a
componenttext: One last one here on the managed accounts, I think you mentioned targeting about $6 billion or so in managed accounts. Just curious how you're thinking about what sort of those products would be is it just growing the Robo that you launched recently? Is anything else you just mentioned how you think about going to managed account strategy rather?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's really our existing suite of product, right? We have our managed account, we have the Robo offering that's out there. And even this past quarter, we saw when we put a little bit of marketing juice behind it that we do have some decent returns on it,
componenttext: It's really our existing suite of product, right? We have our managed account, we have the Robo offering that's out there. And even this past quarter, we saw when we put a little bit of marketing juice behind it that we do have some decent returns on it, right? The growth $175 million from approximately $100 million last quarter. So we're getting there. But I think in terms of their retirement or the longer-term investing assets, what we really need to do is get our name out there. Make sure that given our own customers are aware that we offer those products because we have a nice suite of products to go with. So it's really more of it goes hand-in-hand with what Rodger is talking about with getting better at marketing and putting it out there, but it would be the existing suite. There are no plans right now to expand.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Devin Ryan with JMP Securities.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Devin Ryan with JMP Securities.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: You've spoken about being disciplined financially. If you look at inorganic growth and I think there would be some scarcity in certain areas of the business that you could look at. So you called OptionsHouse a full price and so just trying to think about
componenttext: You've spoken about being disciplined financially. If you look at inorganic growth and I think there would be some scarcity in certain areas of the business that you could look at. So you called OptionsHouse a full price and so just trying to think about kind of that versus the comment that you would be financially disciplined if you look to do something. Is there a rate we should think about and a deal? I guess, what makes a deal good financially?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, before I turn it over to Mike, we absolutely said that we paid a full price. But I believe, we paid a fair price and we do expect to get quite a bit of value out of that acquisition for our shareholders and for us. So we're very disciplined in that
componenttext: Well, before I turn it over to Mike, we absolutely said that we paid a full price. But I believe, we paid a fair price and we do expect to get quite a bit of value out of that acquisition for our shareholders and for us. So we're very disciplined in that one as well. But, Mike, you want to add some color on it?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean, the most important criteria is going to be return on invested capital. We're going to look for invested capitals that are higher than our cost of capital. With that in mind, the relative size or riskiness of the acquisition means that, that
componenttext: Sure. I mean, the most important criteria is going to be return on invested capital. We're going to look for invested capitals that are higher than our cost of capital. With that in mind, the relative size or riskiness of the acquisition means that, that spread needs to be probably larger for riskier acquisitions than for one that had less risk. But they have to achieve a rate above the cost of capital. Additionally, earnings accretion is important. Now that will depend on deal size. It will depend on a lot of other factors in the deal. But it's going to be important that we have meaningful accretion relative to the size of the deal. And then lastly, looking at the question of overall ROE, making sure that we are building a return on equity on the pro forma combined entity. These are the metrics that we're going to look at carefully and hold any deal to in terms of providing value to shareholders.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then coming back to brokerage growth just want to dig in a little more and thinking about closing that gap with peers. I mean, is catching up really in areas where peers are growing faster? Or is it each rate is going in a differ
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then coming back to brokerage growth just want to dig in a little more and thinking about closing that gap with peers. I mean, is catching up really in areas where peers are growing faster? Or is it each rate is going in a different path over time? And just really trying to think about kind of the buckets that you laid out on trading customer engagements. We touched on marketing. But what other specific initiatives are there that really you think can move the needle?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So, look first and foremost, I think is getting OptionsHouse fully integrated, right? Being able to offer the #1 options trading platform to all of E*TRADE customers is a huge thing. So we're pushing pretty heavily on getting that done and wrapped up so t
componenttext: So, look first and foremost, I think is getting OptionsHouse fully integrated, right? Being able to offer the #1 options trading platform to all of E*TRADE customers is a huge thing. So we're pushing pretty heavily on getting that done and wrapped up so that folks have access to that. Second thing is really focusing on being a trading firm again, right? Focusing on our active trader base and on the folks who want to interact with us on a daily basis and making sure that we're providing them the tools to do so. At E*TRADE, we always have a fantastic interface in E*TRADE Pro, rolling out to our customers that they could interact with. And we've lost a bit of luster on that and we're putting it back. So we think catching up is not enough for this management teams so where we are we like to catch up. So working out on the technology front, making sure that we're keeping current with all the products and services that are out there and making sure that we're offering the best possible interaction on the derivatives trading side, right, whether that be options or futures. We'll get there very quickly if we can integrate this as well. So it's really getting back to our roots, but catching up alone isn't just going to do it for us.

componenttext: Yes. 56 is the total balance sheet size. So that's not all 11. You can pack in how much that's going to be of the 11, the growth will continue past that point. componenttext: So I think the deal rule at its core, it makes sense, right? Because it's something we should always be operating in the best interest of our customers at all times. componenttext: Well, any customer that opens up an account that is in the extended sweep deposit issuance program would immediately be placed to the program. That said, it's not really a default customers have a choice of sweet options and continues to be a free credit or payable in the broker when they open the account. headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good evening, and thank you for joining E*TRADE's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Joining the call today are Executive Chairman, Rodger Lawson; Chief Executive Officer, Karl Roessner; and Chief Financial Officer, Michael Pizzi. Today's call
componenttext:
Good evening, and thank you for joining E*TRADE's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Joining the call today are Executive Chairman, Rodger Lawson; Chief Executive Officer, Karl Roessner; and Chief Financial Officer, Michael Pizzi. 
Today's call may include forward-looking statements, including statements about our future operational and financial performance and synergies related to the OptionsHouse acquisition, which reflect management's current estimates or beliefs and are subject to risks and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ materially. 
During the call, we will also discuss non-GAAP financial measures. For a reconciliation of such non-GAAP measures to the comparable GAAP figures and for a discussion of additional risks and uncertainties that may affect the future results of E*TRADE Financial, please refer to our earnings release furnished on Form 8-K and our 10-Ks, 10-Qs and other documents the company has filed with the SEC. All of these documents are also available at about.etrade.com. Note that we have not reconciled our forward-looking non-GAAP measures, including non-GAAP adjusted operating margin to the most directly comparable GAAP measures because material items that impact that measure are out of our control and cannot be reasonably predicted. This call represent information as of October 20, 2016. The company disclaims any duty to update forward-looking statements made during the call. 
This call is being recorded and a replay will be available via phone and webcast later this evening at about.etrade.com. No other recordings or copies of this call are authorized or may be relied upon. 
With that, I will now turn the call over to Mr. Lawson. Please go ahead

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pattison, thank you very much and good evening, everyone, and thank you for joining us. We are at a critical juncture for E*TRADE and this last quarter was particularly significant. While all of you tune in are certainly aware of the more headline-inducin
componenttext:
Pattison, thank you very much and good evening, everyone, and thank you for joining us. We are at a critical juncture for E*TRADE and this last quarter was particularly significant. While all of you tune in are certainly aware of the more headline-inducing changes we made, I'm going to take a few minutes to reiterate the emphasis for those changes before getting a bit of color on the board's current thinking about what constitutes success. And then finally, provide my observations of the company's current trajectory from my new unique vantage point as an insider. 
First of all, our decision to replace the CEO. E*TRADE has spent the last several years appropriately focused on the most impactful opportunities in its past, namely managing the wind down of the legacy balance sheet, bolstering its risk and operating foundations, improving all factors in its regulatory standing and, of course, unlocking and deploying a meaningful amount of capital to the benefit of the shareholders. Many of these efforts were interdependent and somewhat set in motion many years ago. But over the last 3 years, we've harvested most of the fruit of this labor, and the stock appreciated in commensurate fashion. During that period, the board has vigorously supported the management team in pursuing all of those matters. 
At the same time, however, we, as a board, always remained fully cognizant to the need to develop ongoing avenues of growth and value creation once its fixed story have been executed. Key to that growth has always been our core brokerage business. And as you would expect, we've remained particularly focused on the major business driver metrics of accounts, DARTs and assets. I believe our business driver focus has always been thoughtful and certainly alert to the impact of the [indiscernible] of the markets. But having said that, as a board, we have become increasingly concerned with both current business driver results as well as the forward trajectory. 
Given that we face 2 choices, give us more time or take action. We also managed the latter and made changes at the top of the company. Again, the former CEO was a good steward of the company through its recent chapter. But we believe shareholders are better served with the reconfigured executive team to align the company for future growth. In putting together that team, we strongly believe that Karl Roessner was a natural choice to lead E*TRADE. Karl has a deep history of the company, substantial experience and knowledge across all elements of E*TRADE's business, a sharp commercial acumen and is a truly trusted partner to the board as well as an ongoing creditor [ph] presence with our regulators, which you all know is extremely important. 
Additionally, capitalizing on the completion of our OptionsHouse acquisition, Karl, again, with strong support from the board, has taken advantage of an opportunity to fill an important gap in our brokerage leadership, with the appointment of Michael Curcio as our Chief Brokerage Officer. Bolstered [ph] by the continued and noteworthy service of Mike Pizzi, as CFO, along with other leaders, the board feels truly confident that this structure and this executive roster is well suited to accomplishing our goals. 
As for me, I've joined the team in a full-time role as Executive Chairman to ensure Karl has [ph] access to my years of industry experience as well as to support the board's agenda on a daily basis while working constructively with Karl and the management team. My role is not a permanent one, and I look forward to returning to nonexecutive chairmanship in due time. 
With the leadership team in place, however, I want to stress that we are not just looking to implement the right structure, but to drive tangible results to shareholders, which brings me to my next topic. 
What constitutes success for the company? In short, there are 3 areas: growth, improved operating leverage and a sense of urgency. I'll touch on each of these, none of which are mutually exclusive and then pass it over to Karl to elaborate further. 
Starting with our growth ambitions. Balance sheet expansion and breaking through the $50 billion threshold is well underway and is in a more-than-capable hands of Mike Pizzi and his team for implementation. I'm sure that we will discuss further today. 
Our growth focus on what we characterize as key business drivers comes in 2 flavors: organic and inorganic. Organically, the key growth levers are well-known, namely how we market our company to customers and prospects; how we package and promote our products; and finally, how we capitalize on the corporate services channel to drive more meaningful activity. By addressing these elements, we feel strongly that the company can make up lost ground relative to our industry peers. And as previously stated, we quantify that as a 2 to 3 percentage point improvement in our rate of annual organic growth across accounts, assets and trades. 
Inorganically, growth may come from [indiscernible] opportunities as well as adjacent ones, provided an acquisition supports our core business and aligns with our digital ethos. There is currently plenty of public chatter surrounding this topic, and I won't indulge it further. Allow me to say this, the E*TRADE Board is highly value conscious and the company's leadership is smart and methodical in their evaluation process. Translation, we will not overpay and we will not do anything stupid. 
Moving now to improving operating leverage, our perspective is very simple: we must find money to spend money. In this regard, this team is steadfast in their commitments in managing expenses through an operating margin framework, and -- Karl will speak more about this. But I'll mention that I've been impressed with how methodically the new leadership team has driven this goal forward in just a few weeks. I'd also add that this is an ongoing dynamic process. We will always be looking to enhance our operating leverage in the future, both through sound management as well as the intelligent application of technology. This is an attitude possessed by all good companies and is most certainly not a once-and-done approach. 
Now what do we mean by a sense of urgency? Philosophically, we believe it falls on the board and the senior management team to create and establish an ongoing sense of urgency in our business endeavors. With our capital initiatives and options relatively clearly defined, it's time for the core brokerage business to embrace initiatives and move forward more quickly. As a board, we certainly believe the new company leadership team can produce the desired results. It is critical that we also set it by a series time line for that to unfold. 
Last month, I said that was 18 to 24 months at which point the board will take stock and assess options for the company if our goals are not achieved. That time line stands and has been embraced by management as motivation to get things done, and I find that extraordinary encouraging. 
Finally, I would like to share my observations for the company from the inside. I'm impressed with the management team's ability under Karl's leadership to make difficult decisions to drive results and to focus on our goals. This includes the work to integrate OptionsHouse, the meaningful changes to our organizational structure, and the intense drive to address expense issues. I'll let Karl speak to his team's work, but I'll just say the board is pleased with our state of play. 
And with that, I'll turn it over to Karl.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rodger. It's a pleasure to speak with you all. I wanted to start by building on Rodger's observation with my own. With 7.5 years in the company, I can confidently speak that I've never seen our leadership team act with more purpose or cohesiv
componenttext:
Thank you, Rodger. It's a pleasure to speak with you all. I wanted to start by building on Rodger's observation with my own. 
With 7.5 years in the company, I can confidently speak that I've never seen our leadership team act with more purpose or cohesiveness than it has over the past month. I'm truly impressed and believe we are all growing in the same direction. This is largely attributable to how we've realigned the team, but certainly aided by that board encouraged sense of urgency that Rodger mentioned. I will start with the executive leadership team and the changes we made. 
First, with our most crucial goal centered on the brokerage business, installing a strong brokerage head was a key priority and Mike Curcio has definitely filled that role. Next, to centralize functions to directly support our business goals, I moved marketing and corporate services from the executive office to Mike Curcio's organization. Further, we removed an inefficient senior layer of business line COOs along with an unnecessary support and consulting structure across the company. It's easy to speak to growth, but if the internal environment isn't conducive to execution, it can be an impossible order. So we have made all of these changes with an eye of getting back to our lean, scrappy brokerage roots. Separately, we have consolidated oversight of our compliance and AML functions under Paul Brandow as Chief Risk Officer, aligning the structure to be consistent with industry standards and regulatory expectations. All of these organizational changes foster a more accountable and collaborative culture, one which I believe will produce measurable, positive results and one which comes at a significant savings to the P&L. 
To be clear, we have a sense of urgency and are focused on results. The key priorities to which we will hold ourselves accountable are: integrating OptionsHouse. This one's pretty obvious but it sits at the top of the list because of the importance that hangs on getting this right. It's imperative that we capture the full value associated with the deal, and we're on track to accomplish this. 
Refocusing on trading. We were once the undisputed leader in this space, but have notably fallen behind. We need to reearn this top spot and the purchase of OptionsHouse is only the beginning of these efforts. 
Deepening engagement with existing customers. Reinforcing our long-term investing offering remains a crucial component of our efforts. We offer the same products and services that many of our customers use elsewhere and need to create greater awareness of these offerings, particularly through our marketing efforts. 
Finally, never losing sight of all that we've accomplished on the risk and regulatory fronts. These key priorities are meant to improve performance across our core metrics and specifically generate accounts and asset growth and trading activity where, as Rodger noted, we're targeting a 2 to 3 percentage point improvement in our annual rate of growth. 
Additionally, we're turning up the focus on our derivatives mix, with an aggressive target of growing it to 35% of DARTs within the next 2 years. Further, with respect to long-term investing, we aim to grow our managed product AUM to $6 billion within the next 2 years. 
In tandem with our commitment to grow the business, we also understand our responsibility to be good stewards of shareholder value through operational efficiency. As a management team, we took a hard look at our operating model during the quarter, considering the impacts of the OptionsHouse acquisition and of our organizational realignment. As a result, we identified significant cost savings in the combined organization to be realized as part of our mandate to become more nimble while maintaining our strong risk culture, where I believe we are standard bearers in many respects. With regard to our $49 million of deal-related expense synergies, we have completed $15 million as of this call, with the balance expected to be realized by Q3 of next year when we complete the OptionsHouse integration. Also related to the close of the transaction, we had a $7 million charge in the restructuring line. 
Separately, following a focused review of our structure and expenses, this quarter we have eliminated an additional $21 million of annual run rate expenses. The restructuring line also reflects charges of $18 million, primarily related to these actions. 
Moving on to our results. We reported net income of $139 million or $0.51 per share. There's a decent amount of noise in these results, which boosted the bottom line by $19 million or $0.07 per share in total. On a pretax basis, these items were $6 million of severance related to our prior CEO, the $25 million of restructuring- and acquisition-related expense I just mentioned and a $62 million provision benefit. 
On the metrics, excluding the OptionsHouse accounts we acquired, we added 14,000 net new brokerage accounts during the quarter, and our attrition rate was a healthy 8%. Our brokerage account growth rate was 1.7% for the quarter, down from 2.8% in the prior quarter. We also added $1.7 billion in net new brokerage assets, excluding OptionsHouse asset, which compares to $1.6 billion in the prior quarter and $2.1 billion a year ago. We ended the quarter with $307 billion in total customer assets, including $24.4 billion in fee-based assets, which are predominantly mutual funds and managed products. We ended the quarter with $3.7 billion in managed product AUM, including $176 million in adaptive portfolio, our newly launched robo-solution. 
Our DARTs for the quarter were 152,000, flat with the prior quarter and down 3% year-over-year. Excluding OptionsHouse, our DARTs would have been 146,000 for the quarter, down 4% sequentially and down 6% year-over-year. The quarterly decline reflects some seasonality and a fairly quiet macro market environment. The year-over-year comparison is a tough one given the turmoil in global markets that led us to a single-day trading record in August of last year. Approximately 26% of our DARTs were in derivatives in Q3, which includes a 1.7 percentage point boost from OptionsHouse over the final 15 days of the quarter. Pro forma with OptionsHouse for the full quarter, derivatives would have been 30%. Our customer margin balance has ended the quarter at $6.8 billion, including approximately $300 million from OptionsHouse. 
In closing, we're working hard to align the organization and all of our efforts for growth, and I'm confident in our ability to achieve our goals. I hope my remarks serve to show that we mean business when it comes to growing our business. I look forward to delivering and to keeping you all apprized along the way. 
I'll now turn it over to our CFO, Mike Pizzi.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Karl. For the quarter, we reported net income of $139 million or $0.51 per share. This compares to net income of $133 million or $0.48 per share in the prior quarter. It also compares to adjusted net income of $96 million or $0.32 per share in
componenttext:
Thank you, Karl. For the quarter, we reported net income of $139 million or $0.51 per share. This compares to net income of $133 million or $0.48 per share in the prior quarter. It also compares to adjusted net income of $96 million or $0.32 per share in the year ago quarter, which excludes $430 million of pretax charges related to the termination of wholesale funding obligations. 
Revenues for the quarter were $486 million, up $8 million from the prior quarter, largely related to higher customer cash held by third parties and up $55 million on an adjusted basis from the year ago quarter, which is attributable to the benefits from our wholesale funding termination and the Fed rate hike. 
Net interest income was $287 million for the quarter, up $1 million from the prior quarter as a 5 basis point reduction and net interest margin was offset by a $1.1 billion larger average balance sheet. Our net interest margin of 259 basis points decreased primarily due to faster prepayment speed on the securities portfolio, continued runoff of higher yielding legacy loan -- of the legacy loan portfolio and an unfavorable shift in margin balances to lower-priced tiers. Our average reinvestment rate is now in the range of 175 to 200 basis points. We continue to expect our full year net interest margin to be 260 to 265 basis points with Q4 in the mid-250s. This also assumes no change in the Fed fund's rate and that margin balance has remained constant with their current levels. 
Commissions, fees and service charges and other revenues were $185 million, up $7 million from the prior quarter and up $50 million versus the year-ago quarter. Compared to Q2, commissions revenue increased $1 million as DARTs were flat and average commission per trade increased $0.15 to $10.97. This was driven by higher options and stock plan mix. Relative to the year-ago quarter, commissions revenue decreased $1 million on lower trading activity, partially offset by a $0.10 increase in the average commission per trade also related to higher options and stock plan mix. Our DARTs of 152,000 this quarter include 6,500 from OptionsHouse for the 15 trading days of the quarter that they were under our umbrella. 
Fees and service charges revenue increased relative to both the prior quarter and the year-ago quarter. We recorded a $3 million sequentially increase on customer cash held by third parties as off-balance sheet cash grew amidst customer net selling. Meanwhile, we had a marginally higher average yield on these balances following the conversion of $4 billion of money market funds into our sweep program in early September. The $16 million year-over-year change reflects higher yield on third-party customer cash as well as an increased asset -- as well as increased asset-based fee revenue. For some context, the average yield on customer cash held by third parties was 47 basis points, up 6 basis points from Q2 and up 29 basis points from Q3 of last year. We expect this rate to move in line with broader short-term benchmark rates. 
The fees and services -- the fees and service charges line also contains approximately $3 million from OptionsHouse, which includes revenue from their customer margin and cash balances. Once we convert their third-party clearing arrangements in Q3 of next year, we will capture this revenue through NII. 
Securities and other gains were $14 million, up $10 million from the prior quarter as we reposition portions of the portfolio around Brexit-driven market volatility. For Q4, we expect gains to return to the $10 million range. 
Noninterest expense for the quarter was $323 million, up $28 million sequentially, including the unique items Karl mentioned. Our adjusted operating margin, which excludes provision, was 34%. This was driven lower by approximately 6 percentage points related to CEO severance, restructuring and acquisition-related costs. For Q4, we expect our adjusted op margin to be approximately 35%, which reflects the full quarter impact of OptionsHouse. 
Moving to the provision line. We recorded the benefit of $62 million for the quarter. The allowance ended at $235 million, a reduction of $58 million in the quarter as net charge-offs were a recovery of $4 million. The current period provision benefit resulted primarily from updated performance expectations based on sustained outperformance of high-risk HELOCs. The current period also reflected recoveries in excess of prior expectations as well as payoffs on loans converting to amortizing. We are now 73% through the HELOC conversions, providing ample data on the performance of these loans. 
Additionally, the portfolio continues to reduce in size ending the quarter at just $4.1 billion, down $315 million from the prior quarter. Further, our allowance coverage ratio remains healthy at 6% of the total loan portfolio. 
Moving on to capital. We distributed $125 million up to the parent during the quarter, including $85 million from the brokers and $40 million from the bank, which was below Q2 bank net income of $106 million as we preserved capital at the banks to fund planned balance sheet growth. I'd note that with respect to brokerage distributions in connection with the merger of our clearing and securities entities, we intend to distribute approximately $100 million to the parent in Q4. In the future, brokerage distribution should be consistent with excess capital generation. As for the bank, we intend to utilize the majority of its capital generation to fuel our balance sheet growth, but plan to distribute $50 million to the parent this quarter. 
On assets, we ended the quarter at $49.2 billion and have our sights on crossing $50 billion in the first half of next year. With significant customer net selling of $2.4 billion in the quarter, the conversion of $4 billion of money market funds to our sweep program and the addition of OptionsHouse, off-balance sheet customer cash is $14 billion. With around $3 billion now available to bring on -- not available to bring on balance sheet on a pro forma basis, we are just shy of $11 billion of cash for balance sheet growth. 
On a related note, with work on the enhanced regulatory build-out well underway, we feel good about crossing $50 billion in the first half of next year and anticipate ending Q2 with total assets of approximately $56 billion. As for the cost of the build-out, we continue to expect $50 million over 2 years with $15 million in annual run rate expense. The cost we have incurred to date are minimal and are included in our adjusted operating margin guidance for 2016. 
The bank's leverage ratio of 8.5% implies about $180 million of capital above our current 8% target. We intend to seek regulatory approval to lower that target to 7.5% early next year, which would free up an additional $180 million. As for parent capital, we ended the quarter with Tier 1 leverage ratio of 7.3%, down from 7.5% last quarter, but above our floor of 7%. Corporate cash ended the quarter at $306 million, a decrease of $217 million from the prior quarter. We issued $400 million of 5 7/8 Tier 1 qualifying noncumulative perpetual preferred stock during the quarter to partially fund the purchase of OptionsHouse. The remainder of the $725 million purchase price was funded with cash, thus contributing to the decrease during the quarter. This was partially offset by $125 million of subsidiary dividends. Barring any other attractive uses for parent cash, we will be in a position to resume share repurchases in the second half of 2017. 
To briefly summarize, Q3 was a busy quarter. We completed a meaningful acquisition, made progress achieving our expense synergy targets, aligned the company through a focus on core growth, identified additional cost saves, positioned the balance sheet to deliver considerable incremental value, and continue to exhibit marked progress on reducing risk. 
And with that, operator, we will open the call for questions.
