componenttextpreview: Sure, Rich. You've heard me say for some time that we've been seeing the data come in at or better than our modeled expectations. What you have this quarter is really a recalibration of those expectations and that is why the release is larger or increasin
componenttext: Sure, Rich. You've heard me say for some time that we've been seeing the data come in at or better than our modeled expectations. What you have this quarter is really a recalibration of those expectations and that is why the release is larger or increasing. We finally have a sample size large enough to really recalibrate the allowance process and model based on the amount of conversions that have been coming through. And so this amount that's being released catches it up to that new guidance. So from a look forward perspective, the best guidance I can give you is 0.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay. And I'll just do one follow-up here. But I guess, the question is, Rodger, you've laid out the 2% to 3% growth target and over an 18- to 24-month period, we're not going to talk directly about any acquisition or M&A activity. But I guess, I wo
componenttext: Okay, okay. And I'll just do one follow-up here. But I guess, the question is, Rodger, you've laid out the 2% to 3% growth target and over an 18- to 24-month period, we're not going to talk directly about any acquisition or M&A activity. But I guess, I would like to know what happens if you don't beat that 2% to 3% hurdle in that time period.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, Rich, thanks for the question. This is a very important question, a lot of people I'm sure are thinking of the same question. So thanks for asking it. In terms of my response, let me give you a little bit of context and I may answer this question sl
componenttext: Okay, Rich, thanks for the question. This is a very important question, a lot of people I'm sure are thinking of the same question. So thanks for asking it. In terms of my response, let me give you a little bit of context and I may answer this question slightly longer than normal. We picked the 18 to 24 months because, I think, we all thought that was an adequate time to really show the board and to show shareholders that we could get along the growth map that we described at the Barclays conference. Actually we talked, Rich, more about organic growth and it may well be that an inorganic opportunity comes along during that process. But just with 18- to 24-month period, we thought it was adequate time to show we could deliver. And I think from a board point of view, we need to feel very, very comfortable that we can continue to add shareholder value. So now let's go to the potential outcomes and to the heart of your question. Let's take a negative outlook first. What happens if we can't deliver? We conclude that we cannot get to those kind of growth rates and that we can't, therefore, continue to deliver shareholder value. And I think there are a series of options, more options than one might think. The one which obviously everyone goes to is a sale. But there may be other options in terms of partnerships; we have weaknesses, we note them in our business model. If we cannot correct them ourselves, it may be feasible to correct them with partners. But clearly, a sale, partnerships, there are a series of different scenarios which crop up. The only thing I would say, which is definitive is that the board will not allow loss of value. Now having said that, I looked at the positive side, let's assume we do deliver, which -- because it goes both ways and I recognize your question was what if we don't. Let's assume we do deliver, we actually at this moment in time really consider that is possible, wherein -- just speaking for myself, but I know I speak for Karl and Mike and Brett, we're very, very impressed with what's happening here. And there's a real commitment to deliver on the growth drivers that we talked about at the Barclays conference. There are a body of people at E*TRADE who really want to succeed and want to see the company succeed. So even though we're talking about what happens if we don't succeed, I think it's not out of order to say that we believe very strongly we will. Now having said that, I'm sure we have the odd cynic in the phone audience who would say that's just words, but it gives you a little reminder. I came on this board at the beginning of 2012, along with my board colleague, Betty Zager [ph], from Charles Schwab. And I remember at that time, Rich, a lot of doubts are being expressed on whether we could deliver on what I characterize as a low-hanging fruit, but it really was tough to achieve. A lot of doubts were being expressed then. Could we refinance that debt? Could we improve our funding cost? Was our portfolio going to drown us? What's going to happen to the HELOCs? Will we be able to get the benefit of our DTA given the fact that the DTA -- if you're not earning, how the hell can you use your DTA? And so -- and I think that doubt, by the way, wasn't my interpretation of body language, I mean the share price sucked; it was somewhere in middle or low single digits. And yet 4.5 years later, here we are. So I think at that time was real doubt as to whether the management team could deliver. Rich, I think we put our money where our mouth was and delivered. Good credit to them. So now, where do we go with the next 24 months, we will, as a board, seriously consider how we're doing and we'll consider all options. So this is not -- we usually out on anything, we will consider all options, we understand what our role is and the value we have to deliver. But I will say, again, given the kind of people we've got at E*TRADE, I think we believe that we could achieve the value goals we will set. And we clearly that will mean an improvement in shareholder value as we go forward. So I've given you a longer answer, Rich, than the question you asked. But I hope it at least illustrative of what our thinking is.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Steven Chubak with Nomura.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Steven Chubak with Nomura.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Rodger, I really appreciated all the detail you provided to the last question. I'm going to take a slightly different take here. As we think about some of the best avenues for creating long-term shareholder value and you certainly framed it in that con
componenttext: So Rodger, I really appreciated all the detail you provided to the last question. I'm going to take a slightly different take here. As we think about some of the best avenues for creating long-term shareholder value and you certainly framed it in that context in terms of how you're thinking about the long-term brokerage strategy, can you articulate specifically how improving the organic growth profile by 200 to 300 basis points would justify operating on a stand-alone basis and is maybe a better alternative or more accretive path versus a combination with one of your largest brokerage peers?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Steven, it's actually a very, very good question. I can't tell you what the precise algorithm is that says 2% to 3% equals an accessible level of shareholder appreciation. But what I would say that, that level of growth gets us to market standards b
componenttext: Well, Steven, it's actually a very, very good question. I can't tell you what the precise algorithm is that says 2% to 3% equals an accessible level of shareholder appreciation. But what I would say that, that level of growth gets us to market standards because that's how far we're behind. It will run through -- assuming we acquire the types of accounts and the types of trading activity and the types of margin that all things you obviously are very well aware of. And we have absorbed this huge amount of fixed expense in the company over the course of the last 2 or 3 years. Remember, seeing some of the prepared remarks addressed the fact that we really have fixed the operating foundation, I think were the words we used, of the company. So I think the reality is that level of growth will get us to a rate of return, which I think is comparable to our competitors in terms of the organic growth. We did say 18 to 24 months. The world doesn't end at the end of 24 months, I think we'll be continuously reviewing that. We do have weaknesses in the business model, we recognize that. We would be happier if we have developed the RAA channel, we don't have it. Clearly, if we could have one acquired inorganically or at a sensible price, I think it will make us more competitive. But I think the 2% to 3% will deliver comparable rates of increased return. I think it also is a rallying cry for getting all the troops in the company to pursue what has to be done in order for us to be as competitive as we are. But having said all of the above, it's -- there really is never an end date. It's a continuous evolution, and we're going to have to keep evolving the company as we go forward.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for all that color Rodger. Maybe switching gears for a moment, but still I guess, focusing on the strategy but thinking about things in an M&A context. I recognize that you're not going to speak about recent announcements from some of your competit
componenttext: Thanks for all that color Rodger. Maybe switching gears for a moment, but still I guess, focusing on the strategy but thinking about things in an M&A context. I recognize that you're not going to speak about recent announcements from some of your competitors, but just looking at the broader M&A landscape and opportunity, I'm wondering whether you would consider large-scale acquisitions during this current 18- to 24-month time window. It sounded like you might consider some opportunities, maybe enhanced capabilities, but I'm speaking specifically by any large-scale opportunities given that you're still working through an OptionsHouse integration and could that impact your appetite or willingness to acquire any other properties?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So, look -- it's Karl. So looking at sort of where we are right now and what's happening out in the landscape, just keeping in mind, the management team and the board of this company are always focused on what's going to drive our company value, more impo
componenttext: So, look -- it's Karl. So looking at sort of where we are right now and what's happening out in the landscape, just keeping in mind, the management team and the board of this company are always focused on what's going to drive our company value, more importantly, what's going to drive shareholder value. So if there are acquisitions out there, whether it be a scale acquisition or if it were to be a product extension or a channel that we don't have right now that could drive revenue. And when we looked at it as methodically as we do anything that we look at, if it were to drive shareholder value, we'd definitely be interested, right? But we take a look at it through the same lens, we communicate with our regulators, make sure that everybody was sort of teed up on it before we move on it. We're very disciplined in our approach to things. We have to be.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Steve, I'll just add a comment to that. We're always going to look at acquisitions, maybe just because we're nosy and we want to know what the competition's up to, or it may well be because they represents a real opportunity to grow scale or enhance o
componenttext: And Steve, I'll just add a comment to that. We're always going to look at acquisitions, maybe just because we're nosy and we want to know what the competition's up to, or it may well be because they represents a real opportunity to grow scale or enhance our business model, which are driving issues. So we're always going to look.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Okay. And then just one more modeling question for me if I may. And maybe it's better suited for Mike. But you mentioned that the servicing -- the service charges and fee line, there are various puts and takes so you have to consider the Option
componenttext: All right. Okay. And then just one more modeling question for me if I may. And maybe it's better suited for Mike. But you mentioned that the servicing -- the service charges and fee line, there are various puts and takes so you have to consider the OptionsHouse contribution. But presumably, there is some benefit from off-balance sheet deposits, which will go away. How should we think about the run rate for that line item once all of the off-balance sheet deposits have been swept to the bank and you have the full contribution from OptionsHouse?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Once you all the -- if you just look at the amount of off-balance sheet cash, at $14 billion is predominantly now all in the Sweep Program. That's going to shift down. About $3 billion of that will remain off balance sheet. The rate they came in this
componenttext: Yes. Once you all the -- if you just look at the amount of off-balance sheet cash, at $14 billion is predominantly now all in the Sweep Program. That's going to shift down. About $3 billion of that will remain off balance sheet. The rate they came in this quarter is really market-determined. And so that market-determined rate will move with benchmark rates, both LIBOR and Fed funds rate.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Chris Harris with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Chris Harris with Wells Fargo.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question on your margins. I appreciate the guidance for the fourth quarter, but there's a lot of moving parts as we get into 2017. So any comment or anything else you guys can kind of guide as to how we should be thinking about the trajectory of your ma
componenttext: A question on your margins. I appreciate the guidance for the fourth quarter, but there's a lot of moving parts as we get into 2017. So any comment or anything else you guys can kind of guide as to how we should be thinking about the trajectory of your margins as we get into next year?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Chris. There is a lot of moving parts and we're going to have a lot more to give you firm guidance on when we complete our budget and capital planning process, which we're in the midst of now. So we will give you a firm target. Right now, with the in
componenttext: Yes, Chris. There is a lot of moving parts and we're going to have a lot more to give you firm guidance on when we complete our budget and capital planning process, which we're in the midst of now. So we will give you a firm target. Right now, with the integration of OptionsHouse, you can see that the OptionsHouse margin is maybe a little bit lower than ours is driving the Q4 margin down a bit on an adjusted basis. We think as the synergies come online, that operating margin improvement from the acquisition will come through. And we should be operating next year to comparable operating margins to this year, but we'll be back with more specificity on that at the next call.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then one quick other question here on expenses. The run rate savings you guys have talked about $21 million. Can you expand a little bit on where that came from? Is any of that in client-facing positions? And is that sufficient enough to
componenttext: Okay, great. And then one quick other question here on expenses. The run rate savings you guys have talked about $21 million. Can you expand a little bit on where that came from? Is any of that in client-facing positions? And is that sufficient enough to cover your growth expenses for next year?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the $21 million really came from the elimination of the positions that I talked in the prepared remarks. And just looking at our organization and really getting alignment throughout, particularly on the brokerage side itself, making sure that the right
componenttext: So the $21 million really came from the elimination of the positions that I talked in the prepared remarks. And just looking at our organization and really getting alignment throughout, particularly on the brokerage side itself, making sure that the right pieces are all under Mike Curcio, so that we can get appropriate execution and deliver on some of the growth that we've talked about. We don't plan on that $21 million that came out funding growth or otherwise. If we are going to continue to grow and continue to find new projects to invest in, we'll have to find that within the business. And as Mike just laid out, we plan to sort of stay within the op margins that we've been at now. I think we've said that a couple of times now, so happy to repeat it. Nothing was customer facing, right? We don't intend to impact the customer in that way. These are really just looking through and garnering efficiencies that have gotten the right people and the right places to do that job.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from the line of Conor Fitzgerald with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Next question comes from the line of Conor Fitzgerald with Goldman Sachs.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rodger, maybe just to start with you. I think you talked about you felt that there was a lack of emphasis on growth and then it came out short versus the board expectations. Can you give us a little more color on where exactly you felt the strategy fell s
componenttext: Rodger, maybe just to start with you. I think you talked about you felt that there was a lack of emphasis on growth and then it came out short versus the board expectations. Can you give us a little more color on where exactly you felt the strategy fell short? And kind of what gives you confidence that the new management team can execute on those targets you laid out?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Conor. Thank you. A good question. I think we all feel that our marketing aggressiveness has been diminished over the course of the last few years. I don't think we've been generating the prospects and the new accounts at a rate which is commensurat
componenttext: Sure, Conor. Thank you. A good question. I think we all feel that our marketing aggressiveness has been diminished over the course of the last few years. I don't think we've been generating the prospects and the new accounts at a rate which is commensurate either with what we were spending or what we've achieved in the past. So without wishing to wash any dirty laundry in public, I think our view would be that we can make material progress in our marketing endeavors. And that I think was a relatively -- that I would say, Conor, is one of the most dominant factor. We, as a company, as you're well aware, have had our distractions over the last 5 or 6 years, maybe that takes some of the emphasis off. But I think we have dropped the ball to a degree. And personally, I think we've taken -- as we ought to great credit for the fact that we have really fixed the foundations of the company as per my prepared remarks. And we've also generated the kind of financial returns, which I alluded to earlier when I said I think there were doubts, we could do it. I think all credit to Michael Pizzi and his predecessor, [indiscernible] and others, because they've really delivered. But I think during that phase, we may have taken our eye off some of the marketing endeavors and we thought that financial success was an end in its own right as opposed to a means to an end. I think now we need to -- as you will note over the course of next few months -- we need to become much more aggressive in that space. And that's why I am personally optimistic that we can make good progress there.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. And when you talk about your marketing efforts falling short, would you consider sacrificing margins in the near term to drive growth longer term?
componenttext: That's very helpful. And when you talk about your marketing efforts falling short, would you consider sacrificing margins in the near term to drive growth longer term?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, you could say we would always consider it. If in fact, it was going to add materially to the value of the company, I think the answer is, yes. Do I think it's likely to happen, which I think is the more pertinent question is, no. I j don't think the
componenttext: Well, you could say we would always consider it. If in fact, it was going to add materially to the value of the company, I think the answer is, yes. Do I think it's likely to happen, which I think is the more pertinent question is, no. I j don't think the opportunities at the moment present themselves, but we're open to it. We were open and the board perspective, the senior management perspective is we want to see the company grow. And I know we over-use that word grow and growth, and whether it's a Barclays conference or now, but we want to see the company grow. And so if there's justification for significant investment in the short term because we cannot only drive share and growth but it has tangible financial value. I mean, we're just not going to add accounts for the sake of it. But if it can drive tangible financial value, we would, we would invest. But again, my only comment at the moment, I don't think we see that opportunity. I don't know, Karl, if you'd like to comment on that.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think that's right. I think the way you sort of laid out where we are right now on the brokerage and the amount that we've invested previously in our foundational efforts, we have to do that. Right? It's a necessary evil that we had to take care of.
componenttext: No, I think that's right. I think the way you sort of laid out where we are right now on the brokerage and the amount that we've invested previously in our foundational efforts, we have to do that. Right? It's a necessary evil that we had to take care of. We had to put ourselves back in a place that we can get the operational flexibility that we now have. And the way I look at it, that same low-hanging fruit that we had on the financial side of the house and the balance sheet, we actually have a lot of opportunities on the brokerage side, right? We're very focused on risk and second, third lines of defense and getting that all cleaned up. And I think we now have an opportunity. But my own humble opinion is we're not going to sacrifice in terms of changing our op margin or eating into the good things that we've already done for short-term wins. So it would have to be long-term value base in order for us to invest in it.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And Mike, just maybe one cleanup question for you, if I could. The operating margin of 35% for the fourth quarter, does that include any integration expenses? And if I kind of back out the severance and integration charges you guys are tak
componenttext: That's helpful. And Mike, just maybe one cleanup question for you, if I could. The operating margin of 35% for the fourth quarter, does that include any integration expenses? And if I kind of back out the severance and integration charges you guys are taking 3 and 4Q, does your 38% margin target for the year still hold?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the -- for next quarter, the 35% includes any planned integration expense as well as having OptionsHouse in the items for a full quarter. Now keep in mind, we are in the midst of an integration and there are things that are planned for next year.
componenttext: Yes. So the -- for next quarter, the 35% includes any planned integration expense as well as having OptionsHouse in the items for a full quarter. Now keep in mind, we are in the midst of an integration and there are things that are planned for next year. If we move faster, that may move some of that into the fourth quarter. Right now, though, that is the plan. So that's the information that we have. In terms of the year, if you look at sort of the onetime items, they're pushing our adjusted operating margin down in the period to 34% by about 6 percentage points. So if you take those onetime items out, which are about $31 million or $0.07 throughout and then take the 35, you'll see that we're coming in on target.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Mike Carrier with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Mike Carrier with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just a question on the expense outlook. So if I look at this quarter, I think on a clean basis you're at 2 92. I guess, first, I just wanted to understand the $21 million that you took out in the quarter, is that sort of in the run rate? Or is there ki
componenttext: So just a question on the expense outlook. So if I look at this quarter, I think on a clean basis you're at 2 92. I guess, first, I just wanted to understand the $21 million that you took out in the quarter, is that sort of in the run rate? Or is there kind of a full quarter in it to see? And then when you guys look at it -- and this is more into '17 -- when you look at it in terms of what you include on the expenses or those target margins, are you including the OptionsHouse, like the integration cost and like the bank cost? Or is any of that going to be like restructuring or acquisition related just so we understand kind of what you're looking at when you're talking about the margin?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the costs for this quarter came in more towards the back end of the quarter overall. So from a run rate perspective, you'll probably see it pick up a bit. Now keep in mind, when we look at next quarter, we will have options -- we get OptionsHouse
componenttext: Yes. So the costs for this quarter came in more towards the back end of the quarter overall. So from a run rate perspective, you'll probably see it pick up a bit. Now keep in mind, when we look at next quarter, we will have options -- we get OptionsHouse in the income statement for 15 days this quarter, it will be in for a full quarter. So that will affect some of those expenses. We're also starting to see some of the commitment that we made on the risk work to get through the $50 billion barrier. Some of those investments are coming through as well. So that's why we're giving you an operating margin target not specific expense guidance. Looking into next year, we think that we would like to give you a target on the January call that will encompass all expected and planned expenses that would include the CCAR expenses, the regulatory build-out expenses for that as well as all of the integration expenses of OptionsHouse.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. And then maybe just on the strategic side. You guys talk a lot about like the brokerage business, yet on the other side, you're growing the bank and you're breaking through the $50 billion. Just like from a strategic standpoint, given the fo
componenttext: Okay, got it. And then maybe just on the strategic side. You guys talk a lot about like the brokerage business, yet on the other side, you're growing the bank and you're breaking through the $50 billion. Just like from a strategic standpoint, given the focus and -- the focus on the brokerage growth, do you think that limits you in terms of your options out there, whether it's on the acquisition side, with regulators? Or is it okay, meaning you go down that path and still have like kind of full flexibility on the brokerage part of the business?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I don't look -- I look at it as we have to grow the brokerage, right? It's who we are at our roots -- we're a retail brokerage and that's sort of what we do every day. And the organizational alignment, the add of OptionsHouse, some of the capabili
componenttext: Yes. So I don't look -- I look at it as we have to grow the brokerage, right? It's who we are at our roots -- we're a retail brokerage and that's sort of what we do every day. And the organizational alignment, the add of OptionsHouse, some of the capabilities that came on were the first things that we've done toward that end. Growing the balance sheet and taking the bank up over $50 billion as long as we do it smartly as we have done around here, will not lead to any additional constraints on other things we're going to do. I mean, Mike Pizzi can talk to you a little bit about capital and some other pieces. But my own view has always been that the bank adds quite a bit of power to our returns. Mike, I don't know if you want to add anything on the capital side or limitations side?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think that the decision around the balance sheet creates any limitation and flexibility. It's going to be a lot of work. We've been organizing around that, building our plans accordingly. And we began to make some progress in all of those key
componenttext: No, I don't think that the decision around the balance sheet creates any limitation and flexibility. It's going to be a lot of work. We've been organizing around that, building our plans accordingly. And we began to make some progress in all of those key areas. But I don't think it limits any flexibility in what we're trying to achieve in the growth of the core business.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Michael Cyprus with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Michael Cyprus with Morgan Stanley.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just curious as you're thinking about accelerated growth here. If you could just talk a little bit how you're using customer data and analytics today to improve your customer acquisition, drive greater engagement and retention? And just longer term, how y
componenttext: Just curious as you're thinking about accelerated growth here. If you could just talk a little bit how you're using customer data and analytics today to improve your customer acquisition, drive greater engagement and retention? And just longer term, how you're thinking about the opportunity set from that?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'd rather approach it from the opportunities perspective because quite honestly, I think we can do a much better job of using data particularly in our marketing efforts and being more direct and sort of smarter in the touches that we have with our cus
componenttext: So I'd rather approach it from the opportunities perspective because quite honestly, I think we can do a much better job of using data particularly in our marketing efforts and being more direct and sort of smarter in the touches that we have with our customers and prospects every day. So that is something that we're focused on. We've just gone through a bit of a restructure in that organization as well; some more to follow, but we will be using data more smartly in the future.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is there anything else on the expense side as you're thinking about that with the attitude to the run rate in order to get there that you think you could flesh out in terms of what specifically this may consist of in terms of trying to monetize that oppor
componenttext: Is there anything else on the expense side as you're thinking about that with the attitude to the run rate in order to get there that you think you could flesh out in terms of what specifically this may consist of in terms of trying to monetize that opportunity set?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. When we look forward -- and we're doing a lot of our planning processes right now -- I think everything is going to be within that operating margin framework.
componenttext: No. When we look forward -- and we're doing a lot of our planning processes right now -- I think everything is going to be within that operating margin framework.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. I think I'll just ask one last one here on the managed accounts, I think you mentioned targeting about $6 billion or so of managed accounts. Just curious how you're thinking about what sort of those products would be. Is it just growing the robo t
componenttext: Got it. I think I'll just ask one last one here on the managed accounts, I think you mentioned targeting about $6 billion or so of managed accounts. Just curious how you're thinking about what sort of those products would be. Is it just growing the robo that you launched recently? Is there anything else you can just flesh out, how you're thinking about growing the managed account and the strategy around that?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it's really our existing suite of products, right? We have our managed account, we have the robo offering that's just out there. And even this past quarter, we saw when we put a little bit of marketing juice behind it that we did have some decent retur
componenttext: So it's really our existing suite of products, right? We have our managed account, we have the robo offering that's just out there. And even this past quarter, we saw when we put a little bit of marketing juice behind it that we did have some decent returns on it, right, to growth it to $175 million from, I don't know, approximately $100 million last quarter. So we're getting there. But I think in terms of the retirement or the longer-term investing assets, what we really need to do is get our name out there, right. Make sure that even our own customers are aware that we offer those products, because we have a nice suite of products to go with. So it's really more of a -- it goes hand in hand with what Rodger is talking about with getting better at marketing and putting it out there, but it would be the existing suite. There are no plans right now to expand.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Devin Ryan with JMP Securities.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Devin Ryan with JMP Securities.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: You've spoken about being disciplined financially. If you look at inorganic growth and I think there would be some scarcity in certain areas of the business that you could look at. So you called OptionsHouse a full price, and so just trying to think about
componenttext: You've spoken about being disciplined financially. If you look at inorganic growth and I think there would be some scarcity in certain areas of the business that you could look at. So you called OptionsHouse a full price, and so just trying to think about kind of that versus the comment that you would be financially disciplined if you looked to do something. Is there a hurdle rate we should think about in a deal? Or I guess, what makes a deal good financially?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, before I turn it over to Mike, I would just say we absolutely said that we paid a full price. But I believe, we paid a fair price and we do expect to get quite a bit of value out of that acquisition for our shareholders and for us. So we were very d
componenttext: Well, before I turn it over to Mike, I would just say we absolutely said that we paid a full price. But I believe, we paid a fair price and we do expect to get quite a bit of value out of that acquisition for our shareholders and for us. So we were very disciplined in that one as well. But, Mike, you want to add some color on it?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean, the most important criteria is going to be return on invested capital. We're going to look for return on invested capitals that are higher than our cost of capital. With that in mind, the relative size or riskiness of the acquisition means t
componenttext: Sure. I mean, the most important criteria is going to be return on invested capital. We're going to look for return on invested capitals that are higher than our cost of capital. With that in mind, the relative size or riskiness of the acquisition means that, that spread needs to be probably larger for riskier acquisitions than for one that had less risk. But they have to achieve a rate above the cost of capital. Additionally, earnings accretion is important. Now that will depend on deal size. It will depend on a lot of other factors in the deal. But it's going to be important that we have meaningful accretion relative to the size of the deal. And then lastly, looking at the accretion of overall ROE, making sure that we are building a return on equity on the pro forma combined entity. These are the metrics that we're going to look at carefully and hold any deal to in terms of providing value to shareholders.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then just maybe coming back to brokerage growth. I just want to dig in a little bit more and thinking about closing that gap with peers. I mean, is catching up really in areas where peers are growing faster? Or is it E*TRADE goin
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then just maybe coming back to brokerage growth. I just want to dig in a little bit more and thinking about closing that gap with peers. I mean, is catching up really in areas where peers are growing faster? Or is it E*TRADE going in a different path over time? And just really trying to think about kind of the buckets that you laid out on trading and deepening customer engagements. I mean, we touched on marketing, but what other specific initiatives are there that really you think can move the needle?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So look, Devin, first and foremost, I think it's getting OptionsHouse fully integrated, right? Being able to offer the #1 options trading platform to all of E*TRADE customers is a huge thing. So we're pushing pretty heavily on getting that done and wrappe
componenttext: So look, Devin, first and foremost, I think it's getting OptionsHouse fully integrated, right? Being able to offer the #1 options trading platform to all of E*TRADE customers is a huge thing. So we're pushing pretty heavily on getting that done and wrapped up so that folks have access to that. Second thing is really focusing on being a trading firm again, right? Focusing on our active trader base and on the folks who want to interact with us on a daily basis and making sure that we're providing them the tools to do so. At E*TRADE, we always have a fantastic interface in E*TRADE Pro, rolling out to our customers that they could interact with us. And we've lost a bit of luster on that and we're putting it back, right? So I think catching up is not enough for this management team sort of where we are. We like to catch up and exceed. So working on a technology front, making sure that we're keeping current with all of the products and services that are out there and making sure that we're offering the best possible interaction on the derivatives trading side, right, whether that be options or futures. We'll get there very quickly if we can integrate this as well. So it's really getting back to our roots, but catching up alone isn't just going to do it for us.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttextpreview: Maybe just a clarification question, Mike, on the balance sheet strategy, the $56 billion. Just to clarify, that's moving the $11 billion of off-balance sheet deposits? And then would that -- just explain is the total balance sheet size, is that correct?
componenttext: Maybe just a clarification question, Mike, on the balance sheet strategy, the $56 billion. Just to clarify, that's moving the $11 billion of off-balance sheet deposits? And then would that -- just explain is the total balance sheet size, is that correct? And then what would the earning assets be?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. $56 billion is the total balance sheet size. So that's not all $11 billion. You can back in to how much that's going to be of the $11 billion, the growth will continue past that point. That's what our expectation is by Q2. The limiting factor is capi
componenttext: Yes. $56 billion is the total balance sheet size. So that's not all $11 billion. You can back in to how much that's going to be of the $11 billion, the growth will continue past that point. That's what our expectation is by Q2. The limiting factor is capital and the 7% consolidated ratio in terms of how fast we deploy, but it's also helpful to deploy in a thoughtful manner over time, building the securities balances in a way to be adding the value that we have been as we select securities. So we think that's really the appropriate rate for the build out.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: And so that would convert to an earnings and earning asset balance of around -- is that around $51 billion then or $52 billion?

componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just maybe, Rodger, another question on M&A and I guess, as the board thought about this new path, have you also thought about the implications from the Department of Labor rule? How that's impacting the wire houses? And how bank str
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just maybe, Rodger, another question on M&A and I guess, as the board thought about this new path, have you also thought about the implications from the Department of Labor rule? How that's impacting the wire houses? And how bank strategies may change from brokerage to fee-based and the role that an online broker could play, the new role that an online broker could play in that dynamic? And with E*TRADE would it make more sense for E*TRADE to be part of a larger broker platform?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that's a very interesting question. And we look at it in multiple ways. Sometimes the cup is half full, sometimes the cup is half empty, depending on which day and the latest information we've got. I think, for -- I mean, obviously, we understand th
componenttext: Well, that's a very interesting question. And we look at it in multiple ways. Sometimes the cup is half full, sometimes the cup is half empty, depending on which day and the latest information we've got. I think, for -- I mean, obviously, we understand the problems, which it represents in terms of the retirement business. But I think overall it is an opportunity for the industry in the broadest sense of the word. I think we view it as an opportunity for ourselves, whether by ourselves or maybe it gives emphasis to examination of the RAA channel and what that could represent for us in one point or another. And then obviously, the RAA channel itself is going to be impacted. But net-net, even with the good days and bad days in terms of how we try to understand it, think it would -- I think we view it as a net plus in terms of an opportunity for us. But Karl's spent more time looking at it. What do you think, Karl?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think the DOL rule at its core, it makes sense, right? Because it's -- we should always be operating in the best interest of our customers at all times. So it makes a lot of sense to me. There's still a lot of unsettled pieces and a lot of uncertaint
componenttext: So I think the DOL rule at its core, it makes sense, right? Because it's -- we should always be operating in the best interest of our customers at all times. So it makes a lot of sense to me. There's still a lot of unsettled pieces and a lot of uncertainty around DOL right now. So I think answering that question is a bit difficult in a vacuum. I'd like to see how it plays out come April and see what the first lawsuits are before we actually sort of move forward with it.

componenttextpreview: Just one for me. So I believe that you used Broadridge for some back-office processing and there is a change of control agreement where an acquirer that has an in-house capability would have to pay perhaps an onerous fee to exit it. Whereas if you were to
componenttext: Just one for me. So I believe that you used Broadridge for some back-office processing and there is a change of control agreement where an acquirer that has an in-house capability would have to pay perhaps an onerous fee to exit it. Whereas if you were to come together with a company that has a Broadridge agreement in place, too, you perhaps be able to extract meaningful synergies from this. So can you give us some color around that Broadridge agreement? And how big a factor it is when it comes to contemplating any potential deal?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I have to sort of look at the actual agreements, we've agreements in place with Broadridge for quite some time and the service level agreements and other pieces are quite voluminous. I don't know the exact answer to your question. Mike, I don't know if
componenttext: So I have to sort of look at the actual agreements, we've agreements in place with Broadridge for quite some time and the service level agreements and other pieces are quite voluminous. I don't know the exact answer to your question. Mike, I don't know if you...

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Look, Broadridge is a very important partner to us. And our most important vendor doing all of our books and records and processing for our customers. And you are correct, so those contracts still have provisions that control movement. But in relatio
componenttext: Yes. Look, Broadridge is a very important partner to us. And our most important vendor doing all of our books and records and processing for our customers. And you are correct, so those contracts still have provisions that control movement. But in relation to your question, it's not going to be meaningful. It's just something you would assess in costs, in any combination. But it's not going to be a meaningful factor in any position.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess just with the change in strategy and the focus on growth, has the appetite to exit the legacy loan portfolio through a sale change at all?
componenttext: I guess just with the change in strategy and the focus on growth, has the appetite to exit the legacy loan portfolio through a sale change at all?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right now, when we look at the legacy loan portfolio, there's really not a transaction that would be -- would add value. In fact, I would say, to transact would be value disruptive. The portfolio is performing quite well. Loans as they convert from IO to
componenttext: Right now, when we look at the legacy loan portfolio, there's really not a transaction that would be -- would add value. In fact, I would say, to transact would be value disruptive. The portfolio is performing quite well. Loans as they convert from IO to amortizing pick up pretty significantly in overall price, and we've been trying as best possible to manage the expense of administrating the portfolio. So while I can't say what it means in the long run, for the foreseeable future, we intend to hold the portfolio.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Doug Mewhirter with SunTrust.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Doug Mewhirter with SunTrust.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question. Your customer cash program, I understand you're sending a lot of -- bringing a lot of money from off balance sheet to your deposit base. So for customers that you acquire organically and new customer signs up through E*TRADE, are al
componenttext: Just a quick question. Your customer cash program, I understand you're sending a lot of -- bringing a lot of money from off balance sheet to your deposit base. So for customers that you acquire organically and new customer signs up through E*TRADE, are all of their deposits, their incremental cash, going to deposits by default? Or do you still have to sort of shunt some of that off balance sheet to manage the growth of your balance sheet?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, any customer that opens up an account that is in the extended sweep deposit issuance program would immediately be placed into the program. And if you think about how that program's going to work of, our bank is going to be one of many banks in that
componenttext: Well, any customer that opens up an account that is in the extended sweep deposit issuance program would immediately be placed into the program. And if you think about how that program's going to work of, our bank is going to be one of many banks in that program, which allows us to take as much of the deposit on balance sheet or off. So it's not specific at a customer level. It's an overall program of which our bank is one. That said, it's not really a default, our customers have a choice of their sweep options and continues to be a free credit or payable in the broker when they open the account. And so those are the -- those in -- or within a government money fund. So the customer makes the choice at the time of the account opening.
